hits.name: Great Blue Hill via Skyline Trail
hits.description: Great Blue Hill via Skyline Trail is a relatively short and moderate hike in the forests of the Blue Hills Reservation. The hiking trail offers great views of the downtown Boston skyline and Eliot Tower is a fantastic lookout point to see the entire Boston region. Although the trail is not too technical, trekking poles can help you keep your footing in tricky and steep areas. There is a parking lot across the street from the Blue Hills Reservation Headquarters off of Hillside Street in Milton. The blue-blazed Skyline Loop Trail begins behind the park headquarters. Take the stone steps up Hancock Hill and follow the winding footpath over the ridge line to Eliot Observation Tower, which sits atop Great Blue Hill. Climb the tower for a panoramic view. To return, cross over the stone bridge to intersection #1066, and turn left to return via Skyline south.

hits.name: Mount Greylock via Bellows Pipe Trail
hits.description: Mount Greylock via Bellows Pipe Trail starts from the Gould Road/Bellows South parking area. Mount Greylock is the highest point in Massachusetts at 3,491 feet and is located in Mount Greylock State Reservation. On a clear day you can see as far as 90 miles away. The Bascom Lodge is also located at the summit. Follow the Bellows Pipe hiking trail to Appalachian Trail and return along the same route. The Thunderbolt ski trail should not be hiked due to extensive erosion from foot traffic. Please follow the Bellows Pipe trail back to the starting point.

hits.name: Mount Watatic and Nutting Hill via Wapack Trail
Mount Norwottuck
hits.description:
Highest peak in the Holyoke range, has commanding views of the entire pioneer valley.

The loop for Mt. Norwottuck combines the Robert Frost trail (orange) and the M&M trail (white).  Start from the Visitor's Center on the combined Robert Frost trail and M&M Trail (orange & white).  Stay left on the Robert Frost (orange) when the M&M splits off.  Eventually you will reconnect with the M&M, and there you will stay right on go onto the M&M Trail (white).  You will then begin an ascent to the summit through ledges.  From the summit continue to follow the M&M trail (white) down and eventually you will rejoin the Robert Frost trail (orange) where you split off on the way up.  Stay left on the combined Robert Frost (orange) and M&M trail (white) to get back to the visitor center.

hits.name: Bash Bish Falls Trail
hits.description:
Bash Bish Falls is a great short hiking trail to the highest waterfall in the state of Massachusetts. The falls are located in Southwestern Massachusetts in the Taconic Mountains of Berkshire County, which neighbors Mount Washington State Forest in Massachusetts and Taconic State Park in New York. The park is maintained by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation.

There are a few access points to the falls and more than one parking lot. You can choose to start from the New York side and cross the state line into Massachusetts or start at either of the two Massachusetts trailheads. Starting at the lower parking area off of Falls Road, this short hike follows a rugged trail along Bash Bish brook through mature forest and over boulders, tree roots, natural stone stairs, and long wooden steps.

You are soon rewarded with a view of the beautiful waterfall. The twin falls cascade into a serene pool. Swimming is not allowed in the pool. Use caution as the stones down around the falls are smooth and slick from years of traffic and it is easy to slip.

hits.name: Rock Circuit: Melrose Rock, Black Rock, and Pinnacle Rock
hits.description: Park at the skating rink. Rock Circuit Trail is marked with white blazes. It is well marked in places but some places it is challenging to follow. This trail tends to go over every obstacle in sight so be prepared to climb.

hits.name: Blue Hills Skyline Trail
hits.description:
The route on this page has the hiker starting at the eastern terminus on Willard Street and completing the route east to west. Hikers can also start from the western terminus. This alternate route can also be found on AllTrails.
 
Blue Hills Reservation is a popular hiking and mountain biking destination located about 10 miles south of downtown Boston. The Massachusetts State Park offers more than 125 miles of trails and is one of the largest parcels of undeveloped conservation land within the Boston metropolitan area. The park offers spectacular views and is a great place to see fall foliage. Visitors interested in the reservation's ecology will enjoy the numerous swamps, ponds, marshes and meadows, as well as a number of endangered species.
 
The Blue Hills Skyline Trail features varied terrain and fantastic views of Eliot Tower and the Boston Skyline. The hiking trail summits a number of hills including Hancock Hill, Hemingway Hill, Wolcott Hill and Great Blue Hill at an altitude of 635 feet - the highest point in the reservation. The trailhead can be accessed from the Willard Street parking area.
 
Horseback riding, trail running and cross-country skiing are also popular activities. Visitors interested in purchasing a reservation trails map for the best trails in the park can do so at the Reservation Headquarters office just along the North Skyline trail.

hits.name: World's End Trail
hits.area_name: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
hits.description:
Rolling hills and rocky shorelines offer sweeping views of the Boston skyline, while tree-lined carriage paths designed by famed landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted make delightful walking trails.

$8 per person for non members/$6 for members/Children get in free.

hits.name: Race Brook Falls and Mount Everett
hits.description: Lots of climbing to kick your butt then a dip in the pond before hiking back.

hits.name: Wachusett Mountain: Old Indian, Stage Coach, Bicentennial Trails
hits.description:
This loop is a combination trail of many interconnected trails at Wachusett Mountain State Reservation. There are many other trails to connect to to shorten or lengthen your journey.

Trails in this loop include:
Bicentennial Trail 
pine Hill Trail 
Old Indian Trail 
West Side Trail 
Semuhenna Trail 
Windmill Trail 
Stage Coach Trail 
Echo Lake Trail 
Echo Lake Road 
High Meadow 
back to Bicentennial Trail

hits.name: Cheshire Harbor Trail to Mount Greylock
hits.description: This is the easiest and shortest ascent route from base to summit of Mount Greylock and the highest peak in Massachusetts. Spectacular views at summit.

hits.name: Great Brook Farm Woodchuck, Chicken, and Beaver Loop Trail
hits.description:
You can park at Farm's Ice Cream Stand for $3 in the summer.

This loop is groomed for cross-country skiing in the winter months and not open to foot traffic during the ski season.

hits.name: Wachusett Mountain via Balance Rock, Old Indian, and Semuhenna Trail Loop
Whitehall Reservoir Loop
hits.description: This route travels around the reservoir starting from the boat launch. Please be mindful and considerate when hiking this trail as parts travel near private property. This is a scenic hike with brief hills and lake views. Seasonally, there is thick cover of leaves and it can be muddy in low spots so wear sturdy shoes. The trail surface has lots of roots and rocks.

hits.name: Charley's Loop Trail
hits.description:
A unique natural landmark, Purgatory Chasm runs for a quarter of a mile between granite walls rising as high as 70 feet. Popular with picnickers and rock-climbers alike, the Chasm is believed to have its origin in the sudden release of dammed-up glacial meltwater near the end of the last Ice Age, approximately 14,000 years ago.

Trails lead to a wide variety of rock formations, with such romantic names as The Corn Crib, The Coffin, The Pulpit, Lovers' Leap and Fat Man's Misery.

hits.name: Southern Middlesex Fells Loop
hits.description: Please note if the reservation parking lot is full don’t park on Governors Ave since it’s permit parking only. Look for parking on one of the side streets.

hits.name: Boston's Freedom Trail
hits.description:
Discover the roots of the revolution and Boston's rich history on this popular walk. 

The Freedom Trail is more than a collection of historic sites related to the American Revolution or a suggested itinerary connecting Boston's unique neighborhoods. The route follows a crimson path on public sidewalks and pays tribute to the figures all school kids know, like Paul Revere, John Hancock, and Ben Franklin. In history-proud Boston, past, and present intersect before your eyes, not as a re-creation but as living history accessible to all.

Boston played a key role in the dramatic events leading up to the American Revolution. Many of the founding fathers called the city home, and many of the initial meetings and actions that sparked the fight against the British took place here. In one day, you can visit Faneuil Hall-the "Cradle of Liberty"-where outraged colonial radicals met to oppose British authority; the site of the incendiary Boston Massacre; and the Old North Church, where lanterns hung to signal Paul Revere on his thrilling midnight ride. Colonists may have originally landed in Jamestown and Plymouth, but if you really want to see where America began, come to Boston. 

The Route:
The Freedom Trail begins at Boston Common, winds through Downtown, Government Center, and the North End, and ends in Charlestown at the USS Constitution. The entire Freedom Trail is marked by a red line on the sidewalk; it's made of paint or brick at various points on the Trail. 

Timing:
If you're stopping at a few (or all) of the 16 sites, it takes a full day to complete the route comfortably. If you have children in tow, you may want to split the trail into two or more days. 

Visitor Centers:
There are Freedom Trail information centers in Boston Common (Tremont Street), at 15 State Street (near the Old State House), and at the Charlestown Navy Yard Visitor Center (in Building 5).

Tours:
The National Park Service's free 90-minute Freedom Trail walking tours begin at the Boston National Historical Park Visitor Center at 15 State Street and cover sites from the Old South Meeting House to the Old North Church. Check online for times; it's a good idea to show up at least 30 minutes early, as the popular tours are limited to 30 people. 

Half-hour tours of the USS Constitution are offered Tuesday through Sunday. Note that visitors to the ship must go through security screening. 

Accessibility: There are designated accessible spaces in the Boston Common Garage parking lot off of Charles Street at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete or brick. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 2.5 and 3.3 miles when going north. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: The Cascades Trail
hits.description: Users report the trailhead can be hard to find and suggest parking by the Y, walking to the front of the elementary school, and finding the trail sign behind the fence across from the school's main entrance. Walk to the right of the sign until you see steps going down which will lead you to the start of the trail.

hits.name: Walden Pond Path
hits.description:
Walden Pond is a kettle pond famous for being home to Henry David Thoreau. This is a narrow trail around the pond. It’s designated as a Heart Healthy trail so some people power walk it, while others take a leisurely stroll.

Part of the Massachusetts Forests and Parks system, Walden Pond State Reservation includes 335 acres of protected open space so that visitors from near and far may come to experience the pond that inspired Thoreau. In summer the Reservation is a popular swimming destination. In the spring and fall, many people hike the trails that ring the pond and visit the replica of Thoreau's one-room cabin. Year-round interpretive programs and guided walks are offered as well as a gift shop, bookstore, and the Tsongas gallery.
 
Parking fee: varies, depending on if your license place is in-state or out-of-state. For updated fees, please visit https://www.mass.gov/locations/walden-pond-state-reservation
The fee is waived with the DCR pass.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Walden Street at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is a natural surface (dirt, leaves, rocks). It is typically at least 3 feet wide with a fence on either side. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. According to the park website, the visitor center and restrooms are wheelchair-accessible. There are beach wheelchairs available on a first-come, first-serve basis.

hits.name: Borderland State Park Loop Trail
hits.description: $5 parking fee unless you have an annual pass.

hits.name: West Middlesex Fells Reservation Bike Loop
Mount Tom Traverse via Metacomet-Monadnock Trail
Great Island Trail
hits.description: This trail follows sandy stretches between the elevated heights of Great Island and Great Beach Hill. Its higher elevations punctuate spectacular vistas which emerge from an even-aged, pitch-pine forest. Part of this trail leads to a colonial-era tavern site (no remains visible). Other sections skirt salt marsh embayments.  A picnic area is adjacent to parking area.

hits.name: Oak Hill
hits.description:
Offline map recommended for this route. Users have reported that the trail is not marked well.

The yellow boundary trail is 3.3 miles long. It has a few hills and lots of nice, wide flat trails. The biggest obstacles are the rocks and tree roots.

hits.name: Battle Road Trail
hits.description:
This partially paved trail is family-friendly and runs the length of the Battle Road Unit of Minute Man National Historical Park. It passes by many historical buildings.

Accessibility: There is one designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Lexington Road at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement (with partial edge barriers), gravel, or a natural surface, and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) sections at about 1.0 miles uphill and 4.4 miles uphill when going eastbound. Hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. 

All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. According to the park website, there are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms in the park and the Minute Man and North Bridge Visitor Centers are wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Mount Tom via New England Trail
Moose Hill, Bay Circuit, Turkey, Bluff and Billings Loop
hits.description: There is a fee to use the trails.

hits.name: Halibut Point Trail
hits.description:
This is a very beautiful state park at the end of land in Gloucester.

A historical interpretive trail around the Halibut State Park and Babson Farm Quarry.  This guide will take you through the woods to a 60 foot deep water-filled quarry and then to the ocean to relax by the sounds of crashing waves.

hits.name: Weir Hill Reservation Trail
hits.description:
Please see the Weir Hill park page for up to date information: http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/northeast/weir-hill.html

The map shown has the starting point at Stevens Pond. There is another entrance about a half mile north on Stevens Street.

This route is marked with yellow blazes.

hits.name: Mount Greylock and Saddle Ball Mountain
Metacomet-Monadnock Trail: Section 7
hits.description: If using Google Maps, be sure it is directing you to the trailhead parking off West St/Route 116 before departing.

hits.name: Blue Hills Skyline Trail: Route 138 to Willard Street
hits.description:
A point-to-point hike across the Blue Hills, mostly following the Skyline trail. Easily done using public transport without the need to drive.

Take a train to the 128 Route station and from there, follow the Blue Hill Drive until you reach a small, easy-to-miss path on the left-hand side of the road, heading downhill. Follow the path under the I-95 and head right, along the I-95 slipway and toward the Little Blue Hill. Beyond the Little Blue Hill, you need to cross a road and head up the Great Blue Hill. Here, the paths become more heavily trafficked and you just need to follow the Skyline and Skyline North signs until the very end. From the end of the trail, take the #8 bus or a short walk to Quincy/Adams stop of the Red T line.

hits.name: Mount Williams, Mount Fitch, Mount Greylock, and Stony Ledge
hits.description:
This is a beautiful hike that starts along Money Brook and follows it to a waterfall.

It's one of the best hikes in the Berkshire region because it features the tallest mountain in Massachusetts. It follows Money Brook at the start, which makes for a very nice gradual beginning to this difficult hike. Money Brook trail starts gradually and works its way up the deep valley between Greylock and Mt Prospect. The trail passes a beautiful waterfall that is worth diverting from the trail for. At the head of the valley the route joins the Appalachian Trail and follows the AT south over Mt Williams, Mt Fitch and on to the Greylock summit, which has pretty good views of Fitch and Williams. The views from Greylock summit are spectacular. Returning from the summit, continue south on the AT to the Hopper Trail and follow it through the campground on Sperry Road and out to stony ledge with spectacular views of Greylock and the Hopper. Take the Haley Farm Trail on the right, which ends up right where you started.

hits.name: Arnold Arboretum Trail
hits.description: Take a break from the urban life and escape to this arboretum for some solitude among the various tree species. This guide covers all the major areas of interest within the Arnold Arboretum located just south of Boston in the Forest Hills area of Jamaica Plain.  This is a great place to go if you want to escape into peaceful surroundings. There are many interpretive signs about the various species of plants you will discover along the walk.

hits.name: Bruce Freeman Rail Trail
hits.description:
Bruce Freeman rail-trail is now expanded into Acton. The new section called Phase 2 begins in Westford at Rt. 27. The new section includes Westford, Carlisle, and Acton. The new section has mile markers. There is a bridge that crosses Rt. 2. Many beautiful upgrades to the new section which is all paved as is the first phase. There are many benches. 

There is a winding section that is pretty fun to ride on that is parallel to some businesses. There is a beautifully engraved granite marker pointing you to which direction to continue with miles listed to the towns on the rail trail. At this marker, the rail trail turns toward Acton or you can ride into a park.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Industrial Avenue at the northeast end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement, smooth, and typically at least 4 feet wide. There are painted dividing lines or metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Wachusett Mountain via Bicentennial and Pine Hill Trails
Wolf Meadow Road, High Rock Road and Tupelo Trail Loop
Keystone Arch Bridges Trail
hits.description: Very easy trail with easy elevation changes.

hits.name: Pearce Lake and Upper Pond Trail
hits.description: Breakheart Reservation features a series of intricate, interconnecting trails. This trail Loops around two of the ponds in the park including the largest, Pearce Lake. If you get off track, there are plenty of signs posted and park rangers to help you navigate. Fishing is available on the lake, and there is a beach to relax at. At the top fo the climb, there are great views over the lakes and to the skyscrapers of Boston in the distance.

hits.name: Great Blue Hill via Coon Hollow Path
Blue Heron Trail
hits.description:
Park at the Kendrick Street lot or at Millenium Park. Some of the 'trail' is on the road to complete the loop, and at times it takes some patience to pick up the Blue Heron signs when it weaves in and out of corporate parking lots. Regardless, the majority of the trail is in marshes or wooded areas, and over the course of the 10 miles the terrain changes often enough to keep things interesting!  

Parts of this trail must not get much use judging by the plants that were starting to encroach.

hits.name: Prospect Hill Park
hits.description:
Prospect Hill Park has reopened as of 11/18/21.

https://www.city.waltham.ma.us/recreation-department/pages/prospect-hill-park

hits.name: Mountain Laurel and Raven Rookery Trail Loop
hits.description: This is a 5 mile loop in Lead Mine Conservation Area. Some sections can be pretty muddy when it's wet.  Park at 10 Shatuck Road. Unfortunately, only a portion of one lake remains.  Two out of the three bodies of water are just fields of grass at the moment.

hits.name: Bare Mountain
hits.description:
This is very quick (30-40mins) but strenuous 1 mile hike, accessible from the Notch parking lot. Take the white blazed Metacomet-Monadnock trail on the ascent to and descent from the summit.

Best view to the north, but not as good as Mt Holyoke. This steep trail gives great quick exercise, so it is heavily used. There is no road to the summit, so less crowded than Mt Holyoke or South Sugarloaf.

hits.name: Mount Greylock via Bellows Pipe and Gould Trail
Peaked Mountain Trail
hits.description:
The reservation lies amid one of the most pristine, undeveloped areas of the state, with broad views of rural and forested landscapes in every direction.  1,227-foot summit.

The ascent from the main entrance to the summit of Peaked Mountain is a 467-foot gain in elevation that is strenuous in places. The summit reveals spectacular views of undisturbed rural and forested landscapes in every direction: Connecticut's Shenipsit State Forest to the south, Mount Monadnock to the north, and Mount Wachusett to the northeast. In between lies a sweep of rolling New England countryside with valley farms and small villages. The Valley View overlook provides views of nearby Boulder Hill and the City of Springfield to the west.

hits.name: Eames Pond via Old Bringham Road Trail
hits.description: Very fun trail with a good mix of terrain and scenery, open fields, woods, rocks, ponds, waterfalls and old buildings. Trail has a plethora of wildlife, azaleas and rhododendrons. Make sure to check the blooming season if you're planning to see the wildflowers.

hits.name: Wachusett Mountain via Balance Rock and Old Indian
Mount Hitchcock, Summit House via Net/M&M and Dry Brook Trail
hits.description: Mountain bikes are allowed on every trail except the Metacomet & Monadnock (M&M), which is the roughly 5-mile east-west section (white blazes) that traverses the Holyoke Range ridgeline.

hits.name: Doanes Falls to Spirit Falls Loop
Sanderson Brook Falls Loop
hits.description:
The route shown here traverses the H. Newman Marsh Trail, Memorial Trail, Mica Mine Road, Observation Hill Road, C.C.C. Trail, and the Sanderson Brook Road. The falls are near the intersection of the C.C.C. Trail and Sanderson Brook Road. If you go clockwise, you'll climb up to the vistas, first and then go down to the falls, before walking back to the parking area along the unpaved Sanderson Brook Road.

This is a terrific wooded trail taking you into the Chester Blandford State Forest through thick wooded areas to a beautiful vista and to the beautiful Sanderson Brook Falls. This trail is especially beautiful in early spring and fall.

hits.name: Minuteman Bikeway Trail
hits.description:
This is a former right-of-way rail trail. It extends from Bedford, MA to Cambridge, MA. You will pass by Sly Pond and other historical parks and monuments on the way. It is all a paved, gentle path and very popular.

Accessibility: There are over 10 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Cambridgepark Drive at the southeast end of the trail. All of them appear to be van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete (with railings at bridges), and typically at least 7 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Horn Pond Trail
hits.description: This multi-use trail circles Horn Pond. There are several other interconnecting trails on the west side of the pond to make this loop longer or to explore without doing the full pond loop.

hits.name: West Middlesex Fells Reservoir Trail
hits.description: This route will take you along the wider, more popular walking path called the Reservoir Trail around the bulk of reservoirs on the west side of I-93.  This path keeps you closer to the water bodies than the other paths in the reservation and the path is preferred by the casual walker who just wants some away time from the city in the woods.

hits.name: Wachusett Mountain via Mountain House Trail
Two Towers Hike
hits.description:
Great views of Boston and beyond from Two observation towers.

Fells is the Saxon word for " rocky, hilly area", the route travels to the higerst points in this section of the reservation, Its rocky and hilly both. On the open areas notice the multitude of scrape marks on the igneous rock, caused by the retreating glaciers. From the two towers get a great view of Boston and the reservation. Youll pass over an old Soap Box Derby track and next to the Sheepfold, where sheep grazed for hundreds of years. Now a popular spot for dogs to run free.

hits.name: Chasm Loop Trail and Purgatory Brook
Sandy Pond Trail
hits.description: Visitors have reported sections of trail on the east side of the pond are closed to restoration. Alternative paths are available paralleling the original path.

hits.name: Massasoit Trails
hits.description: As of February 2020, dam is out so you may have to find an alternative route.

hits.name: Ridge Trail and Saugus River Trail Loop
Skyline Loop
hits.description: Visitors have reported some sections of the trail are not well marked. Keeping the app open to help navigate is helpful.

hits.name: Middlesex Fells Reservation Loop Trail
hits.description: An off line map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked and/or that there may be poor cell reception in this area.

hits.name: Gibbs Mountain Loop Trail
hits.description: This trail has a variety of environments. Different sections of this trail feature completely different scenery and vibes ranging from woodsy to forest ponds to farmland to overgrown areas, meandering hills to ravine to open sun plains. Trail is absolutely lovely. Note that there are parts with very narrow walking path and/or overgrown sides but very navigable. Trail may be difficult to navigate at times so keep your AllTrails trail map handy!

hits.name: Peppercorn Hill
hits.description:
From the trailhead, take a sharp right to begin the climb to the summit of Peppercorn Hill. 

There are limited trail markings with multiple intersecting trails. Follow markings for Walleston Loop, downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating.

hits.name: Harold Parker Loop Trail
hits.description: This Forest, 20 miles north of Boston, has some really incredible mountain bike trails within its boundaries.  There are a variety of trails from roads to paths to single track covering over 35 miles.  Use the included map to guide you on a loop around the circumference of the main trails which passes by several bodies of water where you can also watch for birds.  There are plenty of trails that twist in and out of the track, too many to make turn for turn directions.  Use the track and your phone to guide your trail choices depending on if you are hiking or biking.

hits.name: Atlantic White Cedar Swamp Trail
hits.description: This trail descends through a stunted oak and pine forest into a mature woodland, leads to a boardwalk that winds through the picturesque Atlantic White Cedar Swamp, and returns via the historic “Wireless Road” (a sand road) to the starting location.

hits.name: Fresh Pond Reservation Loop Trail
hits.description:
This is a nice paved walk around the 155-acre Fresh Pond Reservoir.  There is one main path around the pond with options for short side trails. There are three main entrances at Alewife Brook, The Cambridge Water Works, and Glacken Field but you need to be a Cambridge resident to park here.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Fresh Pond Parkway at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Bridges, Rusty Car and Lakeside Loop
Boston Harbor and Castle Island
hits.description:
This is a great, family-friendly, paved walk around a causeway to a historic fort that you won't want to miss.

This is a very beautiful area just south of Boston.  You will walk around an enclosed bay past a beach, a WWII memorial, and then to one of the country's most famous forts which were built to defend the city of Boston.  The lawn around the fort is also perfect for a picnic lunch.  Keep your eye out for planes overhead (close overhead) from Logan airport as well as kiteboarders zooming around in the bay.

Accessibility: There are at least 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of William J. Day Boulevard at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with partial railings), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line or metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. According to the park website, there are wheelchair-accessible picnic tables along the route.

hits.name: Charles River Pathway Short Loop
hits.description:
This leisurely ride takes you to some of Boston's wonderful waterways, following the beautiful and historic Charles River on both the Boston and Cambridge sides as you make your way towards Boston Harbor. This tour is an excellent introduction to the paved bike paths and includes some of the best views of the city. This area is great for children and inexperienced riders.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Cambridge Street at the northeast end of the trail. However, the Charles/MGH Red Line Station is accessible. The trail surface is pavement (with partial railings), smooth, and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Cochichewick Loop
hits.description:
Please see the Weir Hill park page for up to date information: http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/northeast/weir-hill.html

Beautiful trail for a longer walk in the area that offers lake views and hills in a mostly wooden environment.  Trail is open year around, however, some parts become excessively muddy during the early spring months.

hits.name: Douglas Forest Wallis Pond Loop Trail
Cascade Falls Loop Trail
hits.description: A great hike if you'd like to take a step out of Worcester and experience nature close-by. The waterfall is gorgeous especially in Spring when wild flowers bloom along the trail. Many side trails allow this short walk to be turned into an afternoon hike. An old dump with interesting objects can be found in the woods on the opposite side of the loop from the falls.

hits.name: Frank Knowles Little River Reserve Loop
hits.description:
The crown jewel of DNRTs Little River Reserve is the Boardwalk Trail, which features a 200-foot-long boardwalk and viewing platform.

The Frank Knowles-Little River Reserve is part of a 500-acre block of publicly accessible protected land surrounding the headwaters of Dartmouths Little River. Visitors can explore nearly 9 miles of hiking trails that wind through wetlands covered with ferns and mossy boulders, hillsides dominated by hulking yellow birch and white pine, glades of austere beeches, wide expanses of salt marsh, and old fields teeming with wildflowers and birdlife. A network of stone walls and several historic farmhouse and barn foundations harken back to the days when farms covered the land. The large contiguous forest areas make excellent wildlife habitat, including breeding habitat for bird species such as barred owl, wood thrush, and veery.

hits.name: Sand Dune Trail
hits.description: This is a social trail and not officially maintained. This is a trek over impressive sand dunes to the beach.  Walking up and down the sandy dunes can be fairly challenging especially on a hot day but you'll be able to cool off with a swim once you reach the beach across the dunes.

hits.name: Wolcott Hill Loop Trail
hits.description: The Wolcott Trail is quiet, easy, and gently sloped for a good portion of it and the Eliot Tower has great hill trails but can be very busy. The section of north skyline is fun but not easy! The level forest track back to the beginning is a welcome change of pace. Offline map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked.

hits.name: Houghton's Pond Recreation Area
hits.description:
The Houghtons Pond Recreation Area offers a variety of recreational activities, including swimming, fishing, picnicking , and hiking as well as a playground, concession  pavilion, and Visitors Center.

Located only minutes from the bustle of downtown Boston, the DCR Blue Hills Reservation stretches over 7,000 acres from Quincy to Dedham, Milton to Randolph, providing a green oasis in an urban environment. With its scenic views, varied terrain and 125 miles of trails, the Blue Hills Reservation offers year-round enjoyment for the outdoor enthusiast.

hits.name: Pine Hill, Harrington, Jack Frost, Bicentennial, and Mountain House Trail Loop
hits.description:
Parking fee:
MA resident  $5
Non-MA resident  $20

Rising above the surrounding forest to a height of 2006 feet, Mount Wachusett stands as a unique landmark within the central New England landscape. From the summit, a clear day reveals views of Mt. Monadnock in New Hampshire, the Berkshires to the west, and the Boston skyline to the east. The 3,000-acre Wachusett Mountain State Reservation surrounds the summit and offers a wealth of natural and recreational resources. The Reservation's natural resources include forests, alpine meadows, ponds, streams, fields, and even a perched bog. Recreational opportunities abound at the reservation including hiking, nature study, hawk watching, picnicking, and skiing. The Reservation offers 17 miles of hiking and walking trails.

hits.name: Middle and North Reservoir Loop
hits.description: Sections of the trail are not marked well, having the map accessible is helpful for navigating.

hits.name: Mount Greylock Overlook Trail
hits.description:
Overlook Trail can be considered primarily a connector trail between the Hopper Trail and the Summit of Mt. Greylock. It offers one scenic vista with limited views and easy to moderate terrain.

Begins at Mt. Greylock Summit and descends through varying ups and downs to the Hopper Trail.  You may also take the trail from the Hopper to the Summit.

hits.name: Hickey, Peeskawso and Mohican Monument Loop
hits.description: In April of 2021, Squaw Peak was renamed Peeskawso Peak, and the Indian Monument Trail was been renamed “Mohican Monument Trail” by The Trustees of Reservations who oversee Monument Mountain, in coordination with local tribes. More info can be found at https://www.news10.com/news/monument-mountain-trail-and-peak-renamed-after-discussion-with-native-tribe/

hits.name: Lake Rico and Big Bearhole Pond Trail
Buffumville Lake Loop
hits.description:
Almost 500 acres of land comprise the natural environment at Buffumville Lake. Forms of recreation include fishing, hunting, seven miles of multi-use trails, and group picnic shelters. The lake is also popular for canoeing, kayaking and primitive boat-in camping.

Buffumville Lake is a 200-acre (0.81 km2), 5.2-billion-US-gallon (20,000,000 m3) capacity United States Army Corps of Engineers flood control lake project located in Charlton, Massachusetts. The lake and surrounding grounds are open to the public for hiking, boating, fishing, and hunting. A 27-hole frisbee golf course is located next to the lake. Buffumville Lake is managed as a unit with the nearby Hodges Village Dam flood control project.

hits.name: Hoosac Range Trail to Spruce Hill
Mount Holyoke Summit via NET/M&M Trail
Laurel, Main and Pine Trail Loop
Breakheart Reservation Loop
hits.description:
A nice paved path around the park suitable for the whole family. Beautiful scenery and lots of single-track and fire road paths throughout the reservation. There are plenty of spaces to enjoy, a playground for little kids, a volleyball area, a gorgeous beach, and a picnic area.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Forest Street at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 1.0 to 1.9 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Ponkapoag Pond Loop
hits.description: Easy to moderate loop right off the highway. Good for bird watching, walking and trail running.

hits.name: T. Bagg, NET/MM and Keystone Trail Loop
hits.description: This trail is stunning! Lots of pretty forest and some nice outlooks! The trails are not marked very well, so offline map is handy. In some seasons, it can get icy in some spots, so micro spikes highly recommended.

hits.name: Ashuwillticook Rail Trail
hits.description:
A beautifully resurfaced trail following along a reservoir and creek between the mountains sporting fall colors. Gorgeous views along this wonderful trail.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Berkshire Mall Road at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a moderately steep (5-8%) section at about 9.9 miles downhill when going northbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. According to the trail website, there are wheelchair-accessible picnic tables with a firm and stable path and surface and wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the route.

hits.name: Upper Charles Rail Trail
hits.description:
Although currently only 13 miles long, this rail-trail will eventually be a total of 24 miles long. While the whole route is long, segments are family-friendly and great for a weekend adventure.

Accessibility: There appear to be 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Cedar Street at the west end of the trail. Two spots have a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement or gravel (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) sections at about 1.9 miles uphill and 9.6 miles downhill when going northbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas and grade. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Danforth Falls Loop Trail
hits.description: Danforth Falls Conservation Area in Hudson MA is a short hike through the woods along Danforth Brook with a small waterfall. The parking lot can accommodate 2 or 3 cars.

hits.name: Vetter Trail and Ward Trail Loop
Nashua River Rail Trail (from Ayer to Nashua)
hits.description:
The Nashua River Rail Trail is a 12-mile trail connecting Ayer, MA to Nashua, NH. It is a former railroad right of way that travels 11 miles through the towns of Ayer, Groton, Pepperell, and Dunstable. 

The trail offers a 10-foot wide paved surface for the entire length and a 5-foot wide gravel equestrian path for seven miles of the trail from Groton Center to the New Hampshire border in Dunstable. The entire trail is open to pedestrians, bicyclists, inline skaters, wheelchairs, and cross-country skiers.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Main Street at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel (with railings at bridges) and typically at least 5 feet wide. There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved section. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Overbrook Trail and Trail of the Ledges
Graham Trail to Vetter Trail Loop
hits.description: $5 parking fee

hits.name: Wachuset Mountain via Bolton Pond, Semuhenna, and Old Indian Trail
Caratunk Wildlife Refuge Perimeter Trail
hits.description: Caratunk Wildlife Refuge is a great place to hike on the trails. The refuge is private property, owned by Audubon Society of RI (even though it is located in Seekonk, MA). There are almost 4 miles of trails within the 200 acre refuge. There are several types of habitats including fields, streams, a pond and forest. The trails are well signed and maintained, making the refuge easy to navigate. The barn is home to nature programs, birthday parties, weddings, summer camps and is open for rental within local restrictions. There is plenty of off-street parking. Since it is a wildlife refuge there are rules about collecting/foraging, staying on the trails, not bothering wildlife, etc... Dogs and pets are not allowed. Hours in the winter are 7am to 5pm. Hours in the summer are 7am to 8pm.

hits.name: Hancock Hill and Hemenway Hill Loop
South Sugarloaf Trail
hits.description: Mt. Sugarloaf offers a commanding view of the Connecticut River, the Pioneer Valley, and the Pelham and Berkshire Hills. The Reservation offers picnicking, scenic viewing and hiking. An auto road winds to the summit. Available on the summit is a pavilion for scenic viewing and picnicking.

hits.name: Mount Misery Loop
hits.description: For more info on the loop please visit: https://lincolnconservation.org/tws_holding/mount-misery/

hits.name: Chestnut Hill Reservoir Trail
hits.description: This short loop around Chestnut Hill Reservoir offers nice views of Boston College and of Boston skyline. Great for viewing wildlife and birds.

hits.name: Middlesex Reservoir Trail Loop
hits.description: This is a lovely trail for beginners, it is very well shaded in a nice clean forest, reasonably well marked, and popular with bikes and dogs. There are two points along the trail with a great view of the reservoir. It has enough elevation to make it interesting. It is a great trail running option as well.

hits.name: Tippling Rock & Fords Folly
hits.description:
For most of the trail you will be following the Bay Circuit Trail - Section 8. From parking lot follow salamander trail until BCT junction. Continue straight entering BSA reservation. Follow ridge and bear right to Tippling Rock - good views of the north of Boston on clear days.  

Continue on the Bay Circuit Trail - white rectangular blazes. Cross Brimstone Lane (you will see a parking lot there) and re-enter the woods.  Walk northwest on this trail. At the first, and second intersections turn left. At this point you will be leaving the BCT for a trail that will conduct you to a dam.

This dam is known as Ford's Folly, as it was built by Henry Ford, but it failed to hold water. After you reach the area, you can return via the same trail system, or you can decide to take a walk to the Nobscot Mountain, and return via another of the numerous trails in this area.

hits.name: Assabet River Rail Trail
hits.description:
A nice clean paved trail along the river popular for walking and biking. There is parking at either end of the route.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Rawlins Avenue at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt (with edge barriers at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line or metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) sections at about 1.8 miles downhill and 3.7 miles downhill when going northbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Cape Cod Rail Trail
hits.description:
The Cape Cod Rail Trail follows a former railroad right-of-way through the towns of Dennis, Harwich, Brewster, Orleans, Eastham and Wellfleet, then over a bridge over Station Avenue in South Yarmouth, Massachusetts, connecting to an existing bike path that travels west to Higgins Crowell Road in West Yarmouth, Massachusetts.

Its paved surface, few hills, and well-marked automobile crossings make it ideal for cyclists. The trail has a wide unpaved shoulder on one side to accommodate horseback riding, walkers, and runners. There are many opportunities to get off the trail and visit a beach.

Nearing the southern end, walkers and cyclists may choose to turn east onto the Old Colony Rail Trail which ends at Crowell Road, instead of staying on the Cape Road Rail Trail.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Lecount Hollow Road at the northeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary Trail
hits.description:
The sanctuary is open to the public dawn to dusk only. Please be aware this is private property and this trail requires a pass in order to hike. Please visit their website to obtain one at https://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/ipswich-river


Walk around this short loop to find yourself on wooden paths that will take you past several water bodies and through some beautiful woods where chickadees will readily land on your hand for bird feed that is available from dispensers on the trail.  You'll also check out a cool rock grotto that children can explore around.  Keep your eye out for turtles in the water!

hits.name: Willowdale State Forest Loop from Linebrook Road
hits.description: There are many trails in this area, so hikes can be shortened or extended as desired.

hits.name: Blackstone River and Canal Heritage Trail
hits.area_name: Blackstone River and Canal State Park

hits.name: Dike Trail
hits.description:
A pretty, flat, circular trail with nice views of wildflowers, beavers, and muskrats. The parking area is small and may fill up quickly when busy.

Accessibility: There is one designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Monsen Road at the southwest end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is wooden boardwalks (with railings), gravel, or a natural surface, and typically at least 5 feet wide.

The estimated grade is flat (1% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Finerty Pond via Appalachian Trail
hits.description: A fine hike to a lovely pond. This is a deep woods hike, no views in summer (until the pond) and plenty of rocks and roots. It's definitely moderate, but with some harder passages of short, steep ascents. Take a break at Finerty Pond which is gorgeous and peaceful.

hits.name: Bare Cove Path
hits.description: Historic 469 acre wildlife sanctuary acquired by Hingham through the Federal Lands to Parks Program.  The property was used as a Naval training camp and ammunition depot from 1903-1962.  Plenty of parking on Bare Cove Park Drive near the Model Railroad Club building.  Start south and do a loop around the Back River Path.  Opportunities to explore near the shore (Weymouth Back River) or more inland (Bare Cove Park).  Then continue north on Bare Cove Path up to the docks and memorial to sailors lost during WWII.  Then continue on to the Lincoln Street Bridge and turn back or do the 0.5 mile Stodders Neck just to the north of the bridge.  Meander back the same way or jut into the woods to make it more interesting!

hits.name: Ridge Hill Reserve
hits.description:
This 210 acre reserve abuts the Copicut reservoir and is near the SE Mass Bioreserve and other protected lands.

Several easy-to-moderate loop trails provide access to some very pretty terrain and opportunities for viewing wildlife.  While some parts of the green and blue trails can be narrow and rocky, especially on the hillside, the dirt road which bisects the property provides a gentle access or return from all other trails.  The red trail can be very boggy in places, especially in spring and after rains, but is worth the effort for the presence of the ruins of an old mill.  One warning - the reserve's neighbor to the southwest is the New Bedford Rod and Gun club, so be aware of the signs marking their property and be prepare for the sound of nearby gunfire.

hits.name: Cross Fells Trail and Half Mile Road
Bray Lake Loop Trail
hits.description: One of the most beautiful places one can hike. The trails can be easy to moderate, rocky and muddy at times even some ice if you're out in late fall. The hike up the the trails is definitely worth the beautiful views. Mt. Tom boasts an unparalleled view of the Connecticut Valley north and south, the Berkshire mountains to the west and the Pelham hills to the east. This 2,082 acre facility offers 20 miles of hiking and walking trails; picnicking; canoeing and fishing on Lake Bray; and cross country skiing and ice skating in the winter. Mt. Tom also offers a children's play area.

hits.name: Kitchamakin Hill and Chickatawbut Hill Loop via Skyline Trail
hits.description: Great trail with a variety of terrain and views. There are some solid scrambles and climbs but the top is a nice spot for bird watching.

hits.name: Woolsey, Lookout, Coakley, Weaver, Aspinwall Loop
hits.description: This area has a good variety of wooded trails to explore that are well-maintained and features a nice gazebo.

hits.name: Common Hill Loop
hits.description: In the early spring, you can find vernal pools and evidence of amphibian breeding. As the season progresses, you can find many wildflowers, including wild columbine and various kinds of violets, lady slippers, and jack-in-the-pulpits. You'll also find many ferns, mosses and club mosses here, which flourish in a cool, acidic environment. A hemlock maple forest provides shelter for a variety of woodland birds such as the Winter Wren, Scarlet Tanager and Broad-winged Hawk.

hits.name: Bay Circuit Trail to Friends Trail Loop
hits.description: Sections of the trail are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful.

hits.name: Charles River Reservation Full Bike Loop
hits.description: Follow this guide along the Charles River Bike Path all the way out to the Blue Heron Bike Path in Waltham and back. This guide completes a huge loop of the Charles River all the way to Waltham and back to the Cambridgeside Galleria.  The waypoints are a list of POI's for the most interesting areas of the main Charles River Bike Path but have drawn an accurate track all the way out to Waltham and back if you would like to go that far. Beyond this, the Charles River piddles out into a swampy area then a small river so it's not worth going further.

hits.name: Rice Pond to Lookout Rock
hits.area_name: Blackstone River and Canal State Park

hits.name: Robert Frost Trail to Mount Orient
hits.description:
At 47mi in length, the Robert Frost Trail is one the five longest trails in MA. It spans 10 towns from South Hadley in the south to Wendell in the north.
This page details section #7, running between the Amethyst Brook Conservation Area to Pratt Corner Rd. in Amherst.

Most of this section is lightly-traveled, except for the Amethyst Brook area, which features picturesque brooks and bridges and sees many dogwalkers. The guide describes the section as  "rugged, wilderness-like" and rightfully so. The summit of Mt. Orient, about halfway through, provides limited views south and west.
Dogs are allowed. Mountain bikes are allowed only between May 1st through October 31st.

hits.name: Healthy Heart Trail Kendrick Pond Loop
Deer Island Trail
hits.area_name: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
hits.description:
This path is paved with very little change in elevation. The path offers stunning views of the ocean, of Winthrop, and of the nearby islands. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the small paved parking lot off of Tafts Avenue at the northwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete, smooth, and typically at least 4 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the route that reduces the width. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Steep Hill Beach and Crane Beach Loop
Lowell-Dracut Connector, Bob's Bypass, Upper Valley, and Claypit Brook Trail
Bicentennial, Pine Hill, Loop Trail Loop
Mass Central Rail Trail: Oakdale to Highway 31
Mount Holyoke Summit
hits.description: The trail starts off in the forest, and then a paved road goes to the summit.

hits.name: Tri-State Marker
hits.description: Parking is at Wallum Lake in Douglas State Forest. The hike is on well worn trails and leads to the Tri-State Marker. It also goes through an area that used to be a village of some sort. There are old stone foundations to explore.

hits.name: Sages Ravine via Northwest Road
hits.description: There is little cell service in the area and downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

hits.name: Sperry Road to Stony Ledge Trail
hits.description:
If the gate to Sperry road is closed, users have to walk a little further than is described, but it’s all an easy gravel path.

Follow a gravel road through the camping area at Mt. Greylock to the scenic vista of Stony Ledge which offers beautiful views of Mt. Greylock and other mountains.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1 mile of either end of the trail. The trail surface is gravel or a natural surface and typically at least 6 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first half mile heading northbound. 

The estimated grade is moderately steep (8% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) sections after about 0.5 miles when going northbound. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. Hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance along this entire route due to the consistent sections above a 5% grade.

hits.name: Wolf Meadow Road to High Rock to Dan's Trail Loop
Skyline to Sawcut Notch to The Crags Loop
Stony Ledge Trail
hits.description: Descend from Stony Ledge (Sperry Road) down the old Stony Ledge Ski Trail (which may be accessible for skiing in the winter... google it!).  Return via Stony Ledge Trail or via Roaring Brook Trail to Sperry Road.

hits.name: Green Birdhouse and Orange Goose Loop Trail
Loop, Park and Den Pond Road Loop
hits.description: A slightly more rustic and less traveled path in the Upton State Forest. Loop Rd. is a wide easily traveled path through the woods that leads to Whistling Cave path.  Whistling Cave path is much less traveled and more challenging with a number of small streams to cross and large rock formations (including Whistling Cave).

hits.name: Rice Nature Preserve Trails
hits.description: The Tom Leary Trail is one of several trails in the Rice Nature Preserve in Wilbraham. It is named in honor of Tom Leary and the work he did to establish the Rice Nature Preserve. The map you see here actually has several of the other trails in the preserve included in it in addition to the trail named after Tom. As most of the reviewers have noted, this trail leads to a spectacular view of Wilbraham, the Pioneer Valley, and the Holyoke range. The Open Space and Recreation Plan Committee added a boardwalk to the beginning of the trail to ease any trouble with muddy areas near the trailhead. For more details about these trails, please refer to the Town of Wilbraham's Rice Nature Preserve webpage at https://www.wilbraham-ma.gov/index.aspx?NID=298

hits.name: Natural Bridge Trail
hits.description:
The "natural bridge" for which the park is named, according to geologists, is 550 million year old bedrock marble, carved into an arch by the force of glacial melt water over 13,000 years ago; one of the best places in New England to demonstrate the effects of glaciation. Located off Rte 8. 

Hours for Natural Bridge State Park
Memorial Day through Columbus Day
Sunday - Saturday: 
9:00 am-4:30 pm

hits.name: Rattlesnake Knob via M and M Trail (White)
hits.description: The trail head is off of Bay Road in Amherst, MA.

hits.name: Broad Meadow Brook Trail
hits.description: Only the north-eastern section of the trail (Troiano Brookside Trail) and the dirt and boardwalk Sensory Trail by the Visitor Center are considered wheelchair and stroller friendly by the park website (https://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/broad-meadow-brook/about/trails). The Sensory Trail can be viewed on its own trail page here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/massachusetts/broad-meadow-sensory-trail

hits.name: Nauset Marsh and Nauset Bike Trail
Norwottuck Rail Trail
hits.description:
A nice paved shaded multi-use rail trail with views of the Connecticut River. The route is typically busy on the weekend.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Damon Road at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line or metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Root Canal, Turtle Hill, Nuke Dumb and Snake Trail
hits.description: There are multiple trailheads to this area.

hits.name: Hedge Drive and Mile Circle Loop
hits.description:
The former Moseley family estate on the Merrimack River, this park features 19th century gardens and plantings, rolling meadows, towering pines, and one of the largest naturally-occurring stands of mountain laurel in Massachusetts. Most breathtaking are the ornamental trees and masses of azaleas and rhododendrons that bloom in May and June. An exquisite place for walking, biking, horseback riding and informal picnics. Special Use Permits may be obtained for wedding ceremonies and similar programs.

Cultural events are a regular feature during the summer. During the winter a portion of the park is off limits due to roosting bald eagles, but the remainder provides excellent cross country skiing and winter walks.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Cheshire to Mount Greylock
Rock Circuit Trail to Crystal Spring Loop
hits.description: Counter-clockwise is the way to go since there is a lot of intensity on one side, although if you go in the morning the sun is in your face when you view Boston. Be sure to see the elevation chart - Rock Circuit manages to go up and over every rocky prominence.

hits.name: Sanderson Brook Falls Trail
hits.description:
This route traverses the unpaved Sanderson Brook Road to the falls and then returns to the parking area. The road is inaccessible to motor vehicles.

Hikers wishing to extend their hike could make this into a loop by going up the C.C.C. Trail, going north on Observation Hill Road, and then seeing the vistas on the Memorial Trail.

hits.name: Red Maple Swamp and Fort Hill Loop
Buffam Falls White Trail
hits.description:
An easy and pleasant walk through a hemlock forest alongside running waters.

Protected by the Pelham Conservation Commission and Town of Amherst Watershed land, this area makes for pleasant, and relatively easy walking.  The entire hike is in a hemlock forest that lines the ravines of Buffam and Amethyst Brooks.  These evergreen trees, as well as mountain laurel, make fall, winter and early spring hikes here colorful -- and these are also the times when insect populations are low of non-existent.  The woods also support a variety of mushrooms that are found in abundance during late August and September.

From your car, walk north along the road about 0.1 miles. Across from a steep road, you will see a trail that drops steeply and directly to the confluence of the Buffam and Amethyst Brooks. (This is the entrance indicated on this map.) Alternatively, for an easier/flatter entrance, you can walk an additional 0.1 miles down N. Valley Rd. to the official conservation area entrance, which is opposite the first house on your left. Walk to the wooden bridge just inside the woods, where you will find the white markers of the Metacomet-Monadnock Trail. Cross the bridge and immediately bear right, following white markers, on a wide, hemlock-lined trail alongside Buffam Brook. Some falls are found on your right as you descend further into this dark but beautiful ravine. In just a short distance you'll reach a key junction on this hike, a point overlooking the confluence of Buffam and Amethyst Brooks. This spot stands aside the last of the several smooth-slab falls on Buffam Brook and the steps ahead will lead you down to the bottom of these falls where there is a deep, clear pool. But to stay on this hike, make a left and head east on the M-M Trail, which quickly drops down to the level of Amethyst Brook.

Follow the white markers alongside the boulder-filled Amethyst Brook for about .1 mile to a point where it suddenly drops down to brook level and crosses it on rocks.  This crossing could be difficult during times of high water.  If you can't cross it, turn back.  If you cross, be careful on the rocks, which can be slippery.  Now on the south bank of Amethyst Brook, the trail swings away from it temporarily but continues heading east.  At a point about .75 miles from your starting point you'll come to one of Amherst's reservoirs with its old dam and water-control structures.  At the far end of the reservoir, cross the inlet on a bridge, turn right and return to the north bank.

Only 50 feet from the bridge crossing, turn left (west) leaving the M-M Trail and follow an unmarked trail that parallels the north shore of the reservoir, though high above it.  Although the trail is unmarked, it is generally easy to follow and will lead you back the way you came, though on the opposite side of Amethyst Brook.  When you come to a point where it meets an old woods road that once crossed the brook, turn right onto this rocky and wet road for only 75 feet and look for a continuation of the unmarked trail on your left.  Turn here and follow the path heading east again, high above the ravine.  After a light descent and a swing to the left, you should rejoin the M-M Trail where it overlooks the falls and the meting of the Brooks. From this lovely spot, turn right and follow the white markers back the way you came along Buffam Brook (north and uphill) and out to Valley Road.  Your car is a short walk downhill on the road to the left.

hits.name: Redemption Rock to Crow Hill via Midstate Trail
East Boston Camps and Gould Road Loop Trail
hits.description: Half paved on small residential roads, half dirt trail through Conservation Lands.

hits.name: Skyline Trail, Headquarters Path, and Sawcut Notch Path
Battle Road Trail to William Smith House
hits.description:
The paths here are wide, flat, and easy for runners, wheelchairs, bikes, and or strollers. Several chances to make this route longer or shorter.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be designated accessible spaces off of Old Massachusettes Avenue at the east end of the trail. However, there are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of North Great Road. It has been marked with a waypoint. The trail surface is pavement, gravel, or a natural surface, and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface areas. According to the park website, there are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms in the park and the visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Mentzner Trail and Sparrow Trail Loop
Province Lands Bike Trail
hits.description:
There are multiple access points to the Province Lands Bicycle Trail: Race Point Beach, Herring Cove Beach, Province Lands Visitor Center, and Beech Forest Parking Lot

This trail loops around the Province Lands, passing through pine forests, sandy dunes, and low-lying cranberry bogs. There are connections to both Herring Cove and Race Point beaches, as well as Bennett Pond. Enjoy a nice afternoon bike ride and then cool off at the beach! 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Race Point Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or a natural (fallen leaf) surface, and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The most accessible portions of this trail are the first 2.0 miles heading clockwise or the first 0.5 miles heading counterclockwise. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the moderately steep grade category (8% or less) and the steepest sections are at about 0.5 through 1.5 and 3.6 through 4.0 miles when going counterclockwise. 

Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance along this entire route due to the consistent sections above a 5% grade (especially if using manual equipment). There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible restrooms at the north end of the trail.

hits.name: Ravenswood Park Trail
hits.description: Dogs are allowed off leash on parts of this route. The route follows the Old Salem Road and Ledge Hill Trail.

hits.name: Mount Auburn Cemetery Trail
hits.description:
This cemetery is considered to be one of the first garden cemeteries in the country.  You will find numerous amazing monuments and beautiful grave sights as you walk the myriad of trails or drive the roads.

At the Washington Tower you will have a great view towards downtown Boston.  Bring a camera for this trip.

hits.name: Echo Lake Road, High Meadow, Jack Frost and Harrington Trail
hits.description: Cool trail. Follow telephone lines to top of the mountain. Nice wood setting. Trail slightly unbroken in spots and hard to find. Overall pretty sweet!

hits.name: Little Dome via Sawcut Notch Path
Wachusett Mountain via Echo Lake and Jack Frost Trails
Hopedale Pond Red Loop
hits.description:
A nicely well maintained setting and trails in the small village of Hopedale, MA. The parklands wrap around the scenic Hopedale Pond. Most of the trails are far enough from surrounding homes that you do not feel you are in the boundary of the town. Very quiet and safe. Hours are dawn to dusk.

In 1899, the Hopedale town's Park Commission, consisting of 
Frank J. Dutcher, Charles F. Roper, and George Otis Draper, accepted Manning's proposal for a park of nearly two hundred acres, encompassing the entire shoreline of Hopedale Pond.

hits.name: Babson Reservoir Dogtown Loop Trail
hits.description: Users recommend downloading the maps ahead of time, especially for winter hiking.

hits.name: Shaker Mountain Loop via Shaker Trail
hits.description:
Shaker Mountain, 1,835 feet (559 m), is a prominent peak in the Taconic Mountains of western Massachusetts. The mountain is located in Pittsfield State Forest and is named after the nearby Hancock Shaker Village, a former Shaker religious colony and now a historic site. The summit is wooded and is traversed by the Shaker Trail, a loop trail that begins at the historic site. 

The mountain is wooded with northern hardwood tree species. Wonderful ruins and stone walls to view. Very peaceful location and the trails are not blazed but clearly marked. This hike is moderate to strenuous bring your hiking boots and walking stick.

hits.name: Cat Rock Park Loop
hits.description:
The parking lot on Drabbington Way is strictly for residents only on weekends.

There are private trails and property abutting this park, so please stay on established public trails.

hits.name: Black Rock, Lithia Springs, and Dry Brook Loop
Summit House via Taylor's Notch Trail
Fort River Birding and Nature Trail
hits.area_name: Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge
hits.description:
A great wooded gravel and boardwalk loop with lovely fall colors, meadows of wildflowers, and interesting interpretive signage. Plenty of benches for sitting and nature observing. 

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are designated accessible spaces in the parking lot off of Moody Bridge Road at the south end of the trail. The trail surface is a wooden boardwalk or gravel (with edge barriers and partial railings), and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Babson Boulder, Tarr Trail and Common Road
Sherborn Red Trail
hits.description: This wonderland is a beautiful marriage of the Sherborn Town Forest and the Trustees Rocky Narrows property. Limited parking on Forest Street but a great place to start. The Red Trail leads you down into the lowland marsh area then up to the railroad tracks.  On the other side of the tracks is a beautiful and tranquil pine forest loop.  Don't miss King Phillip's Overlook and great views of the Charles and the Medfield small airplane grass air strip.  Continue on around to the Narrows then down to the boat landing area.  The Red Trail will then lead you back to the parking area.

hits.name: March Cataract Falls Trail
hits.description: Short hike to beautiful waterfalls in the heart of Greylock.  The distance in the description does not include walking from the parking area on Rockwell Road to the tralhead off Sperry Road.  Plan about half hour to access the trailhead from the parking area.

hits.name: Across Lexington (Blue), Geology (Red) and Farm/Wetland (Yellow) Loop
Brackett Pond and Bear Pond Loop
Rock House Reservation Trail
hits.description: The centerpiece of the property is the massive, 20- to 30-foot-high rock enclosure that stands guard over man-made Carter Pond. But visitors who choose to explore the 196-acre tract will find theres plenty more to sample from this multi-faceted greenspace.

hits.name: Mashpee River Woodlands North Trail
hits.description: This is a nice family-friendly trail, easy to walk with great views of woodlands, a river, and a pond. There are also reportedly other trail options in the park including a west trail and a south trail.

hits.name: Bay Circuit Trail to Granite Hills Trail Loop
Pennybrook Road to Steel Tower, Stone Tower, Dungeon Rock Loop
White Hall Road and Park Road Loop
Dungeon Road, Boulder and Under Cliff Path
The Hopper Trail
hits.description:
The Hopper Trail begins on Hopper Rd. in Williamstown, MA and climbs gradually and at times very steeply through old forest growth to Sperry Rd and then up to the Mt. Greylock Summit.

The Hopper Trail is approximately 2.4 mi from Hopper Rd trailhead to Sperry Road and then an additional 1.7 mi to the Summit.  You will need to walk a short distance along Sperry Road to transition from the lower Hopper to the upper Hopper that takes you to the summit.

hits.name: Deep Woods Trail East and West Loop
Harrington, Mountain House, Jack Frost, and High Meadow Trail Loop
Robert Frost, NET, North Side, and Laurel Loop Trail
hits.description:
This trail reference only refers to the section from the Notch Visitor Center to Harris Mountain Rd.

A nice hike through the woods with moderate, varying terrain.  Following this trail to rejoin the M&M will bypass the rocky climb to Mt. Norwottuck.  It rejoins the M&M on its path to the Harris Mountain Road.  Worth a side trip though to the Horse Caves by following straight down white blazes instead of to the left up the trail toward Rattlesnake Knob. There is some difficult terrain with some steep ascents/descents past Rattlesnake Knob.  The starting elevation is 500', Rattlesnake Knob is at 920' but you will end up at 385' with many inclines/declines along the way.

hits.name: October Farm Loop
hits.area_name: October Farm Concord Land Conservation Trust
hits.description: Dogs are allowed on this trail however they are not allowed on the trail located in the neighboring Brewster's Wood Audubon property.

hits.name: Sunderland Caves and Sugar Shack via Robert Frost Trail
Tully Mountain Loop Trail
hits.description: Great short hike.  Strenuous part of hike starts pretty early until you reach summit area.  Great views to the East and of Tully pond.  Return trail has nice easy descent through a hemlock forest.  Well worth effort.

hits.name: Molly's Spring Road
hits.description: Public access to this trail ends at the intersection of the Reservoir Trail. Please do not enter the reservoir area.

hits.name: Tippling Rock to Bay Circuit Trail
Great Island Trail and The Gut
hits.description: This trail follows sandy stretches between the elevated heights of Great Island and Great Beach Hill. Its higher elevations punctuate spectacular vistas which emerge from an even-aged, pitch-pine forest. Part of this trail leads to a colonial-era tavern site (no remains visible). Other sections skirt salt marsh embayments.  A picnic area is adjacent to parking area.

hits.name: Skyline, Sawcut Notch, Indian Camp, and Pipe Loop
Hamlen Woods via Mainstone Farm Reservation
hits.description:
Sudbury Valley Trustees' Hamlen Woods encompasses upland forest and an old reservoir with beaver activity. The adjacent Mainstone Farm CR is a sweeping 218-acre landscape that includes agricultural fields and woodland.

The trails are marked with colored diamond-shaped signs, indicated by the corresponding colored lines on the map. The blue trail will lead you from the Hamlen Woods parking area, north to Reeves Hill Conservation Land, over a one-way route of approximately 1.75 miles. The red trail will take you on an approximately 4.5-mile circuit through all of the connected areas.

The ponds that greet you near the Hamlen Woods parking area on Rice Road were created when Snake Brook was dammed in colonial times, initially to create Rice’s Pond. The dam eventually was enlarged to create a reservoir for nearby Cochituate Village, but its use as a water supply ended in 1929. The banks of ponds and streams here include outcroppings of ancient bedrock, a formation of weathered granite known as “Rice Gneiss” (named for nearby Rice Road)

hits.name: Vaughn Hills Trail
hits.description: A lovely afternoon hike. The variability in the terrain makes this hike a little more interesting and fun. There is some climbing over rocks towards the top, but nothing difficult. The pond is interesting to explore and there are additional trails that skirt around the shore.

hits.name: Arbutus Park and Raven Rookery Trail Loop
hits.description: There are a number of inclines, none are too steep and it’s easy to find footing. Great hike all around.

hits.name: Ridge and Cedar Hill Loop
hits.description: Park at lot then proceed back toward road and down Echo Pond trail to beaver heaven (Echo Lake).  Continue clockwise up to June Pond then up onto the Ridge Trail with lovely Mine Hill to your left.  Take a little excursion up Tower Trail to the Cedar Hill summit.  Come down the Cedar Hill Trail to Noanet Trail to lovely Chickering Lake.  Proceed past the parade grounds and back to the parking lot.  A wonderful loop!

hits.name: Two Bridges and Chapel Falls Trail
Mountain Park Deadtop Loop via B-17 Crash Site
hits.description: This trek starts at the defunct Mountain Park which was a turn of the century amusement park. The course leads you around the fenced-in park and up to the Metacomet-Monadnock Trail which is part of the New England Trail signed off by Obama a few years ago.
