There was a nice waterfall this day as the rain has been steady. One trail option is up the old Mt Tom ski trail, you can see the old ski buildings which are in a state of disrepair. Once on top the white blazed trail leads you across the Mt Tom MM trail with stunning views of Easthampton below. Keep going to Deadtop then the Mt Tom summit before heading down the paved road by the B-17 Memorial site. A Flying Fortress crashed here on return from Grandby, Newfoundland. All aboard were sadly lost. Stop and pray for those young boys, their lives cut short. Return via the reservoir with beautiful views of Mt Tom and the ridgeline you just hiked.

hits.name: The Knob at Quissett Harbor Trail
Crystal Springs and Whip Hill Road Loop
Massasoit Loop
hits.description: As of June 2020, there is construction before middle pond.

hits.name: Gould Trail to Mount Greylock
hits.description:
Nice trail to summit of Mt Greylock from the Greylock Glen. Make a loop by returning down the Thunderbolt Ski Trail. You can also ascend/descend Gould's and loop with Cheshire Harbor Trail via West Mountain Rd parking.

It can get a little tricky to follow the trail at the beginning. Stay focused on the blue blazes. There are lots of water sources to refill.

hits.name: East Middlesex Fells Reservation Loop Trail
hits.description:
Take this mountain biking loop around the East side of the Middlesex Fells Reservation to get away from the city life

Follow this track along the rock circuit route on the east side of I-93 for some great mountain biking trails.  You'll follow this trail over a series of rocky outcrops with views towards Boston in the distance.

hits.name: Race Brook Trail to Mount Race
Shelburne Fire Tower Trail
hits.description: Dogs are allowed on the beginning portion of this trail- If you choose to continue to the high ledges, dogs are not allowed on the high ledges trail.

hits.name: Stow Town Forest Blue, Red and AT&T Loop
Mt. Bare, Mt. Hitchcock, Triple B Trail
Dudley Porter to Shoreline and Castle Trail Loop
Mount Warner Trail
hits.description:
Wander the gentle slopes of this 500-foot hill overlooking the Connecticut River Valley and discover a variety of natural delights.  The trail and area is maintained by The Trustees of Reservations.  The main loop, Salamander Crossing Trail was rebuilt in 2014 and is wonderful.

Old cart paths and woods roads reveal the farming and logging past of this sloping woodland that rises between the energetic college community of Amherst and the broad Connecticut River in the historic village of North Hadley.

Vernal pools shelter and nurture an array of animal and plant species. Come spring, look and listen for frogs and salamanders that emerge to reproduce in these seasonal wetlands.

Ascend through oak, beech, and other hardwoods(and examine their trunks for the nesting cavities of birds and small mammals). Evergreen groves begin further upslope.

Admired and appreciated by locals and visitors alike, Mount Warner stands amid a 500-acre swath of protect land linking nearby Lake Warner to the Connecticut River and other conservation treasures.

hits.name: Backpacker Trail to Bear Paw Loop
hits.description: 1-1.5 hr loop to lovely Beebe Pond and back

hits.name: Jug End Road
hits.area_name: Jug End State Reservation & Wildlife Management Area
hits.description: To reach the trailhead- As you go along Jug End Road for about 1.4 miles, before Guilded Hollow Road, you will see a large parking area on your right with a proper sign and a map board.

hits.name: Lake Quannapowitt Trail
hits.description:
This route is shared by cyclists, walkers, and runners, winding around a lake with a nice downtown area at one end. It is mostly on a sidewalk along a busy street. There is plenty of parking available around the route.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of North Avenue at the west end of the trail. None of them appear to be van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete, and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mount Prospect, Mount Williams, and Mount Greylock Loop via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
In great shape? This is a fantastic way to experience the best of Mt. Greylock State Park.  It makes for either a really long, strenuous day-hike, or a moderate overnighter (The main campground requires reservations May through October, so check Mass.gov if you intend to do this).

The loop starts at the Pattison Rd. crossing of the AT, ascends the northern spine of Mount Prospect 1,500 feet in just under 2 miles, continues to Mt. Williams, Mt. Fitch and the highest point in the state, Mt. Greylock, before plunging south on the AT to the Hopper Trail and down to the Money Brook.  You'll descend 2,200 feet into what's know as "The Hopper," passing through the developed campground roughly halfway.  You'll cross the Money Brook before finally ascending 1,400 feet in just over a mile up the gnarly, southern spine of Mt. Prospect, and trekking across its top en route to the return via AT north and the finish.

After Mt. Williams and Mt. Fitch, before the final push up to Greylock, there's an interesting side-route called "Robinson's Point" where you can get a great view of most of Mt. Prospect from across the Money Brook ravine.  It accounts for a little less than a mile of the total distance, but it's a neat trip through dense-growth forest, and the view from the point really sets the tone for the latter stage of this hike.

Both ascents of Mount Prospect are challenging, and the southern area is definitely bear-country, so use caution and be prepared to turn back.  The Money Brook trail to the AT via Wilbur's Clearing is a fine alternative to the southern section of the Mt. Prospect trail, and less strenuous, though far less rewarding.

hits.name: Nasketucket Bay State Reservation Trail
hits.description: A small (209 acre) state property that's ideal for short, easy hikes.  The area includes fields, framhouse ruins, saltmarshes, forest trails, and even rocky beach.  Short, easy trails branch off the main gravel path.

hits.name: North Sugarloaf via Brookside and Pocumtuck Ridge Trail
Pearce Lake and Upper Pond Loop
Harold Parker (East) and Salem Pond Loop
hits.description: Dogs are allowed off-leash on Harold Parker trails but must be leashed in the parking lot and campgrounds. This particular loop keeps you mostly on narrow, winding, wooded trails that are great for a few walkers and their dogs.

hits.name: North River, Gordon Pond and McMullen Trail
Appalachian Trail from Jug End to Bear Mountain
hits.area_name: Jug End State Reservation & Wildlife Management Area

hits.name: Mountain House Trail to Jack Frost Trail
Goat Rock Trail
hits.description: During July and August the Memorial Park entrance is closed Monday - Friday 8:30am - 2:30pm for the Town of Hampden Summer Camp.

hits.name: Mount Toby via Sugar Farms to Summit to Tower Loop
Cat Rock Loop
hits.description: Parked at Noanet Woods parking area off Powisset Street and headed north toward Strawberry Hill.  Continued around to the east toward Noanet Pond then to Cat Rock in Hale Reservation.  Returned along the east side of the Pond down to Powisset Street then to the parking lot.

hits.name: Wenakeening Woods and Idylbrook Loop
hits.description: Park on Cross Street in Holliston, near the rail trail. Start off south and go around the Old Bog area working your way further south to the Idylbrook Conservation Land area.  Continue around the fields, take in the beaver dam and birds, then head north back up to Wenakeening Woods.  Take a victory lap around the baseball field then back into the woods for the final leg back to the starting point and your car.  Be on the lookout for deer!

hits.name: Hatches Harbor and Race Point Lighthouse
Boojum Rock and Hemlock Pool Loop
Cornel Path to Overlook Trail to Cookie Road Loop
Needham Town Forest and Farley Pond Loop
hits.description: Park in lot off Central Ave in Needham, next to Claxton Fields.  Proceed clockwise down the Blue Trail past the miniature railroad tracks then up to the ledge outcrop.  Scramble up the ledge for a nice view and perspective.  Continue down the Green Trail to the rail trail across the power lines down to Farley Pond.  Return through the Boy Scout camp area and up the road back to the parking lot. Offline map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked.

hits.name: Hamlen Woods and Mainstone Farm Loop
hits.description:
This trail starts on the west side of Rice Road near Wayland. There are many trails in this area, so trips can be shortened or extended as desired. Be careful to stay on public trails, as there are some private trails in this area!

The trail starts in the Hamlen Woods, then traverses into the Mainstone Farm, then takes a right to return to the parking area.

hits.name: John Wing Trail
hits.area_name: Cape Cod Museum of Natural History
hits.description: No dogs are allowed on the trail after May 1 annually.

hits.name: Bay Circuit Trail to Red, Yellow, Blue Loop
Skyline Trail to Kitchmakinh Hill and Chickatawbut Hill Loop
Crane Beach Loop
hits.description: Pets are allowed on Crane Beach from October 1 to March 31. There are NO DOGS from May 1 to September 30. Dogs are not allowed on the loop trail at any time.

hits.name: Bicentennial, Mountain House and Pine Hill Trail Loop
Cooke Road and Cornel Path Loop
hits.description: Offline map recommended. Users have reported that the trail is not marked well.

hits.name: Rock Circuit Trail to Cross Fells Trail Loop
The Willowbrook Farm Trail
hits.description: A very fun trail, easy to moderate. Beautiful fields, woods, and bridged swamp hiking trails. Very pleasant and peaceful.

hits.name: Cedar Hill and Crane Swamp Loop
Boulder Lane, Ayer's Lane, Milliken Memorial Path, and Bancroft Loop
Mount Greylock and Stony Ledge via Hopper Trail and Haley Farm Trail
Echo Pond, Harwood Notch, Ridge, and Chickering Pond Loop
Administration Road, Lower Link, and High Meadow Trail Loop
Big Ring Trail Farmersville Road Loop Trail
hits.description: A great place smack in the middle of Cape Cod.  Descent elevation changes & challenging climbs, but a lot of trails are flat but fun.  A great place to get lost for an hour or a day.

hits.name: Petapawg, Towhee, Harry's and Tri-Town Loop
hits.description:
The Assabet River refuge comprises over 2,333 acres of varied woodland, wetland, fields, ponds and streams, with historical and archeological sites.

The Assabet River refuge comprises over 2,333 acres of varied woodland, wetland, fields, ponds and streams, with historical and archeological sites. It is divided into a 1,900-acre northern section, a 300-acre southern section, and 91 acres scattered along the Assabet River in Stow. The terrain is primarily flat but includes some prominent hills; elevations range from 170 feet near the river to 320 feet on Walnut Hill. Seventy percent of the refuge is forested with pine, oak and maple. There are over 470 acres of diverse wetland habitat including an Atlantic white cedar swamp. This jewel is connected to about 1,000 acres of other diverse protected space.

The Refuge is open year round from one half hour before sunrise to one half hour after sunset. Wildlife-dependent recreation opportunities, including hiking, photography, interpretation, and environmental education, are permitted on designated trails shown on the refuge map. Note that the trail system in the refugue was reworked in spring 2007.

hits.name: Jamaica Pond and Victorian Jamaica Plain
hits.description:
Beautiful walk just outside of Boston.  A perfect family-friendly trail!

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Pond Avenue at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement (with partial edge barriers), smooth, and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) sections at about 0.8 miles uphill and 2.9 miles downhill when going clockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mass Central Rail Trail: Rutland to White Valley
hits.description:
Great for walking, running or biking, trail is wide and many great places to stop and enjoy views. 

Once the 104-mile route of the railroad that ran from Northampton to Boston, the Mass Central Rail Trail is being restored as a multi-use greenway. The trail is visited by Bicyclists, walkers, runners, baby strollers, young cyclists with training wheels, wheel chair users, cross country skiers, and nature enthusiasts. Wachusett Greenways is building the central 30 miles of the rail trail through Sterling, West Boylston, Holden, Rutland, and Oakham.

hits.name: Noanet Peak Loop from Walpole Street
hits.description: Enter Noanet from the trailhead at the end of Cedar Hill Road.  Work your way up to Noanet Peak then bushwack down and around back to the starting point.

hits.name: Marblehead Rail-Trail
hits.description:
A nice gravel rail trail that passes by a lake, wooded areas, and winds through some quiet urban neighborhoods. Starting in Salem, the route heads to and through Marblehead to Beach Bluff.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Canal Street at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with partial railings), gravel, or a natural surface and typically at least 3 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line or metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the natural and uneven surface type. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Reformatory Branch Trail
hits.description:
A great bike path connecting the Minuteman Bikeway in Bedford to Concord the Great Meadows Wildlife Refuge

This route will take you from the Bedford Station and the end of the Minute Man Bikeway to Concord, MA.  This hike includes a very cool side trip around the Great Meadows Wildlife Refuge area so you can hopefully see some birds and other wildlife.  The path around the Wildlife Refuge is gravel, and that section inside the Refuge is closed to bikes.

hits.name: Hellcat Interpretive Trails
hits.description:
This is a nice short trail all on a boardwalk that was recently rebuilt to be fully wheelchair-accessible. The stairs have been removed since redesigning the boardwalk in 2020. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Refuge Road at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is a wooden boardwalk with edge barriers or railings. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting. According to the park website, this trail is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Pratt Farm Conservation and Recreation Area Trail
Roller Coaster Loop Trail from Batchler Street
Great Island Extended Trail
hits.description: This trail follows sandy stretches between the elevated heights of Great Island and Great Beach Hill. Its higher elevations punctuate spectacular vistas which emerge from an even-aged, pitch-pine forest. Part of this trail leads to a colonial-era tavern site (no remains visible). Other sections skirt salt marsh embayments.  A picnic area is adjacent to parking area.

hits.name: Bald Hill Reservation Loop Trail
hits.description: Parking is available off of Middleton Road in Boxford.

hits.name: Weston Reservoir Loop
hits.description:
This is a beautiful loop around the Weston Reservoir. There is a small parking lot at the trailhead. There are several trails off of the map shown here, so the trip can be extended if desired.

This area is popular with dog walkers.

hits.name: T Bagg Trail
hits.description: The T Bagg trail is an out and back trail located in the Mt. Tom State Reservation. The route comes to a T intersection with the M&M trail. Continue 0.7mi to Eyrie House ruins or 0.4mi to the left to Goat peak.

hits.name: Round Pond, Coy Pond, Gravelly Pond Loop
Benedict Pond and The Ledges
hits.description: Park at the Benedict Pond lot (fees payable at certain times of year). Go counter-clockwise on the Benedict Pond Loop Trail (blue blazes) and follow it to the South Eastern end of the lake and then around until you meet the Appalachian Trail (white blazes). There is a sign there that says The Ledges (The Steps on the All Trails map). Follow this up a short sharp ascent until you reach more level ground. Continue on a little way until you reach the Ledges, an amphitheater of exposed rock. You'll know you're there by the view (to the right in the direction of travel). The vista stretches from the South to the North West. Retrace your steps and meet up with Benedict Pond Loop trail again and then take an unnamed single track path North until you reach the junction with Old Beartown Mountain Road. There, you'll pick up the Mount Wilcox trail (this is marked blue and is called the Beartown Mountain trail on the All Trails map) and head back to the pond and the lot.

hits.name: Nahant Bike Tour
hits.description: You will bike along a very long and narrow beach out to the main residential community where you will explore rocky beaches, search out a cave, visit an old artillery fort and explore the grounds of a marine research extension of Northeastern University.  On the way home if the beach isn't too busy you'll even have the opportunity to ride your bike next to the waves!

hits.name: Basin Pond Trail
hits.description: It has a small dirt parking lot (maybe fits 6 cars), has a sign that is at the side of the road that says "Basin Pond". It is a nice, fairly easy trail through the forest and across some very shallow brooks.

hits.name: Winthrop Hill and Bear Hill Loop
Goose Pond Trail

hits.name: October Mountain Loop
hits.description:
October Mountain doesn't have a proper summit, but this hike takes you to the very top tier, and along the way offers a couple of swift-moving brooks and a lake where you can take a dip, if the weather is nice.  The middle section of this hike is remote and quiet, a nice alternative to the busier eastern section of this park.

The Gorge Trail starts off Woodland Rd., about 1.5 miles north of the campground.  Woodland Rd. can get pretty choppy after it's rained a lot, but most passenger cars should find it passable.  There are two Gorge Trails, one south of Felton Lake Brook, one north.  They're both clearly marked, and blue-blazed.  The northern is the harder trek, but takes you closer to the brook for photos.  Start there, then hike up almost 1 mile and 500 feet of elevation to Felton Lake.

At the lake turn left and follow the orange-blazed Switchback Trail up the western side of the mountain.  In about a mile, you'll see the Switchback Connector on your right.  Take that another 1.5 miles to a sharp right at the Roaring Brook (you'll hear it, most days).  The Roaring Brook trail isn't marked clearly, but says "NO ORV" on it, and it's a relatively easy down and up if you want to go take a couple pics.

From this point on the Switchback Trail you climb about a half-mile to an obvious "T" junction, where you turn right onto the Felton Trail (also orange-blazed).  Continue one mile to the Felton Lake turnoff (it says "To Pond" on the sign), and another mile back down to the lake.  Cross over the little bridge and take the southern Gorge Trail back down one mile to the parking area.

Micro spikes are strongly recommended. The trail turn into a frozen river at some points.

hits.name: Bird Street Conservation Area Loop
hits.description:
This loop is a combination of the Green, Red, and Purple Trails.

The map shown is from the Bradley Lessa Park entrance to the trail. There are other entrances on Palisades Circle, Westview Drive, and Bird Street.

Users have reported the trail conditions change frequently, and at times the route could be difficult for horses.

hits.name: Wapack Trail: Mount Watatic to Barrett Mountain
Danvers Rail Trail
hits.description:
A pleasant gravel converted rail-trail popular for cycling or walking that goes by a swamp. Great for walking or biking.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Lowell Street at the southwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is boardwalk (with partial railings) or gravel and typically at least 5 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Wells State Park North and South Trail (Red and White)
hits.description: Wells State Park is a popular 1,400-acre woodland park. The two principal activities are camping and hiking.  More than 10 miles of trails cross the property, which are for hiking only; off-road vehicles may not be used. A popular route leads to the scenic vista at Carpenter Rocks from which the eastern section and Walker Pond can be viewed.

hits.name: Black Rock and Lithia Springs Loop via Dry Brooks Trail
MA NET: Section 7
hits.description: Click on "View Full Map" and the straight line portion of the recording disappears,  which it should.  It doesn't belong and was put there in error.

hits.name: Spring Hill Yellow and Blue Loop Trail
Charles River Southwest Corridor Trail
hits.description:
Beautiful views of the urban landscape. Crossings over the Boston University and John F. Kennedy Street Bridges. 

Accessibility: There is one designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Memorial Drive in the center of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement (with edge barriers and railings at bridges), and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Kennedy Pond Loop Trail
hits.description:
This trail is managed by the Westford Conservation Trust and closely borders the private Bobby's Ranch and Butterbrook Golf Course. Hikers must remain on trail designated trails and be conscious of private property boundaries. 

More info can be found at: https://westfordma.gov/1070/Nashoba-Brook

hits.name: Jericho Town Forest Loop via Warren Avenue
hits.description:
This loop starts at the end of Warren Avenue, at the start of Gun Club Road. There are many different trails in the Jericho and Fiske Town Forests, so your trip can be extended or shortened as desired.

There are other trailheads to this area.

hits.name: Morris Island Loop Trail
hits.description:
When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

On the mainland (Morris Island Loop area), pets are not permitted from May 1st - September 15th. Pets are permitted, while on a short leash, September 16th - April 30th.

hits.name: Medfield Conservation and Noon Hill Lookout Loop
Skyline Loop Trail to Hawk's Hill
Clipper City Rail Trail
hits.description:
A nice paved walk in Newburyport which takes you from the train station to the Merrimack River. The trail is spotted with sculptures and gardens. It is great for walking or biking.

Accessibility: There are 9 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of U.S. Route 1 at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The Newburyport Station is also accessible. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Harold Parker Field Pond Loop Trail
Oak Hill, Powissett Peak, Peabody, Noanet Peak Trail, Noannet Pond Loop
hits.description: Parking Fee: $10

hits.name: Moon Hill Loop via Bay Circuit Trail
Echo Lake via Bolton Pond, Old Indian, and Harrington Trails
hits.description: This is a lollipop trail that begins on the Bolton Pond Trail. It then continues straight on the Old Indian and Semuhenna Trails before veering to the right to join the Harrington, Stage Coach, Echo Lake, High Meadow, Jack Frost, and Link Trails to make the loop. Join the Semuhenna Trail back to the start.

hits.name: Nauset Bike Trail
hits.description:
The Nauset Bike Trail is one of 3 bike trails that are part of the Cape Cod National Seashore. It's a 1.6-mile paved trail leading from the Salt Pond Visitor's Center to the Coast Guard Beach.

The trail provides a great way to get to Coast Guard Beach from the Visitor's Center parking lot. It is windy and hilly at times, which can be difficult for small children.

Accessibility: There are at least 6 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Nauset Road at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with partial edge barriers and railings), and typically at least 5 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. According to the park website, there are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the east end of the trail and the visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Jones Nose Trail
hits.description:
Located in the Mt. Greylock State Reservation, the Jones Nose Trail, (trailhead in the Jones Nose parking lot off of Rockwell Road) is a 1.5m out and back trail or can be used as a link trail to access the AT North to summit Mt. Greylock (+2.9 miles)

Jones Nose trail begins with a gradual ascent across open meadows to its peak where, on a clear day, there are spectacular views.  The meadow is full of various wildflowers and this part of the trail is on the easier side of moderate.  It then enters a forested area where the trail becomes narrow and rocky and increases in difficulty.  It intersects with the AT North (take for another 2.9m to summit Greylock and pass over Saddle Ball Mounain) or follow the CCC Dynamite Trail (very overgrown) toward Sperry Road.

hits.name: Westville Recreation Lake Loop
hits.description:
Westville Lake is situated on the Quinebaug River in the towns of Southbridge and Sturbridge, Massachusetts. Westville offers a variety of hiking opportunities, group picnic shelters, a picnic cove, a large recreation field, canoe/kayak launches, and much more. 

Lake trail connects to 'Grand Trunk Trail', if you want to extend your hike.

Natural Features:
The recreation area features a large open field, a picnic cove with trees for shade on those hot summer days, and beautiful waterside views for wildlife viewing.

hits.name: Alander Mountain and Brace Mountain Loop
Beaver Pond Loop
hits.description:
This hike starts on South Great Road near Lincoln. There is a good amount of parking at the trailhead.

There is private property abutting this park, so please be respectful and stay on established public trails.

The trail starts near Twin Ponds, and then traverses over to Stony Brook South. Eventually you will meet Beaver Pond before looping back and returning to your car.

There is no swimming allowed in Beaver Pond.

hits.name: Kay Bee Trail
hits.description:
Located within the Mt. Tom State Reservation.

Kay Bee trail is an out and back trail located within the Mt. Tom State Reservation.  In order to access the trail you need to follow the accesstrail and then there will be signs to the Kay Bee.  This is primarily out and back as it comes to the intersection with the Keystone Trail.  It is 0.7 miles to the junction with the Keystone trail. There is a long ascent in the beginning.  It can be very muddy and buggy after the rain.

The property features wooded upland, rocky shoreline, and tidal mudflats. Geologic features include Cape Ann granite, glacial erratics, glacial outwash, and moraine.

hits.name: Monument Mountain Summit

hits.name: Southwick Rail Trail
hits.description:
A great paved biking path with beautiful autumn colors, also popular for walking, running, and geocaching. The trail briefly passes into CT at the south end.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Shaker Road at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 7 feet wide. There are a painted dividing lines or metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Cape Cod and Old Colony Rail Trail: Dennis to Chatham
hits.description: Park at Barb's Bike Shop in Dennis where you can rent bikes.  The shop is near the Dennis entrance to the rail trail.  Proceed east through Dennis then on to Harwich and Chatham.

hits.name: Commonwealth Ave Monument Tour
hits.description:
A beautiful walk from Hereford Street to the Public Garden

This guide will take you on a stroll through the history of the United States. You will pass nine different monuments commemorating events and people that changed the history of both the city of Boston and the nation. Take the time to click on each of the informative links attached to this guide for a thorough description of each monument.

You will start near the Fenway exit off Storrow Drive and end up at the Boston Public Garden downtown a mile later.  The Commonwealth Avenue Mall is the narrowest section of the Emerald Necklace Path in Boston and connects the Public Garden downtown to the Fens. If you are interested in further exploration, check the Public Garden Monument tour at EveryTrail.com for which there is a link.

hits.name: Pamet Cranberry Bog Trail
hits.description: There are pet restrictions depending on nesting. Please see the website prior to visiting: https://www.nps.gov/caco/planyourvisit/conditions.htm

hits.name: Old North Bridge Walk
hits.description:
Take a walk through history to the first shots of the Revolutionary War that gave birth to this country.

Take a walk/ride from downtown Concord to where the first shots of the Revolutionary War were fired at British Soldiers.  You'll find several famous monuments, beautiful scenery and a lot of historical information on this journey.  Bring a camera and the family along.

hits.name: Ellisville Harbor State Park Trail
hits.description:
Dogs are not allowed on the beach from April 1 to September 15. This is a short hike with a beautiful view. If you go at low tide you'll probably even see some seals sunbathing on the rocks.

Accessibility: There are no designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of State Road at the west end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is a natural surface (dirt, sand, rocks). It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first about 0.2 miles to the picnic table. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections from about 0.4-0.5 miles when going east. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. There are picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mount Grace Long Loop
hits.description: An enjoyable loop trail with about 1,000 vertical feet of climbing.

hits.name: East Sandwich Game Farm Old Briar Patch Loop
Gould Trail to Mt Greylock Summit
Knife Ridge Trail
hits.description:
This trail is part of a larger trail system in Sturbridge. To access this trail from the parking lot follow the "Arbutus Park Trail" and you will see signs for the "Knife Ridge Trail". 
The trail follows along the top of a ridge and is very narrow and rocky, with steep drops along both sides. It is worth the climb to the top as there are several nice views. If you are hiking with small children you will need to use extreme caution with them. If you decide against going to the top of the ridge, continue along the "Arbutus Park Trail" and it will take you to the other end.

hits.name: Dead Neck Trail
hits.description: This trail is accessed via the Mashpee Town Beach. Dogs are not allowed on the beach from April 1st to Sept. 15th.

hits.description: Moderate / Hard Loop Trail through Douglas State Forest.

Quick climb (60-90 min round trip) from the Reservation Rd. trailhead. This is an out and back hike, entirely on the Robert Frost trail (orange blazes).

The hike is forested, but there is a view from the lookout tower. Possible side trip to Sunderland Caves. Many garter snakes, so step carefully.

hits.description:
This section of the Manhan Rail Trail is between the Cities of Northhampton and Easthampton. The trail continues for several miles into Northampton where it connects with the Norwottuck Rail Trail. 

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Ferry Street at the northeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with partial edge barriers), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There are painted dividing lines or metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.description: Park at the trailhead at the end of Forest Street. Start north toward Upper Carpenter Pond then continue to Carpenter Pond.  Head west next to the new development area bushwacking over to southbound trail. Head south to Messenger then finish the loop back to Forest Street.

This is a paved trail that is good for fitness walking and cyclists. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please use caution.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Concord Road at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 9 feet wide. There are metal bollards at street crossings which reduces the width temporarily. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

This is a beautiful little out and back trail The first part of the trail has a story walk which is great for kids and families.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Old Dalton Road at the south end of the trail. It is typically at least 4 feet wide.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first about 0.7 miles when going north. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections from about 1.1-1.4 miles when going north. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. hits.description: Ample parking on Pegan Lane in Natick at trailhead. Start up trail then go right toward Mumford Forest (across dirt road then into field near farm).  Stay to right to do the "Mumford Loop" which ends at the Charles River Link Trail. Go left then a quick right up to Lewis Hill which brings you back to the Dover side of Pegan Lane. Very nice views from the top of Lewis Hill.  Follow road downhill looking for trailhead on the left. Follow this trail up to the summit of Pegan Hill (410') which is about 50' off trail to the left and marked with a USGS marker.  Continue on trail down to parking lot.

hits.description: This out and back trail follows part of the historic Battle Road in Concord, MA from the parking area at Meriams Corner to the Bloody Angle.  The trail is scenic passing through fields, wetlands, and forest and incorporates many of the sites made famous during the early days of the American Revolution.  Excellent for a light hike or mountain biking.

hits.name: Nahant Trail
hits.description:
This route heads north then back south along Nahant Beach and Lynn Beach. There are beach access points, restrooms, and very little shade along the way.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Wilson Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Bradley Farm Interpretive Trail
hits.description:
Easy hike, mountain views, historical area, interpretive trail

Named for Chief Grey Lock of the Abenaki Indians, Mt Greylock State Reservation contains the highest point in Massachusetts (Mt. Greylock 3,491 ft), Sperry Campground, Bascom Lodge, the Appalachian Trail, and numerous hiking, skiing, snowshoeing, and snowmobiling trails.

The Bradley Farm Interpretive Trail is conveniently located at the Visitor Center, and when inclement weather closes Rockwell Road, it is one of the few assessible trails.  Be sure to pick up an interpretive guide and follow along as you traipse through Ephraim Bradley's 18th century farm land.

The route winds past Eastern Hemlock, Sugar Maple, Black Cherry, Birches, Beech, and White Pine; and opaque white rocks called Quartzite garnish the trail.  Climb over the stone walls that once marked the farm pastures, and catch a glimpse of the Berkshires along the Cliff Loop section.

A very popular rock climbing area in Quincy, Massachusetts just outside of Boston with routes of varying difficulty.

Beautiful rock work, many footbridges, and really neat trail points. A must see, a must hole, and an awesome place for a rugged sprint!

hits.name: Canoe Meadows Wildlife Sanctuary Trail
hits.description: This trail is great for the whole family and weaves through a serene wildlife sanctuary with a varied terrain - woods, meadows, and ponds.

hits.name: Red Fox Trail Loop

hits.name: Millenium Park
Pond Meadow Paved Trail

hits.name: Bernard Farm Trail
hits.description: This is a woodsy hike with well marked blue blazes until the AT, which is white. Easy to follow even when blazes aren't visible. There's an old plane crash wreckage on the left side of the trail about 80% way up. After intersecting the AT, head to the summit of Mt. Greylock which was not much more than a 2.4 mile stroll until the last little bit which is quite steep, but not treacherous. Good views in places.

hits.name: Henry L. Shattuck Reservation
hits.description: The Shattuck Reservation is the lowland sibling to the higher elevation Noon Hill Reservation.  With several opportunities to view the lovely Charles River and walk through colonial era reclaimed pastures, this is a wonderful property.  Park in the shared parking area then start to the right and cross over the dam.  This loop continues across Causeway Street then down to the river.  Making the most of this you can continue to the far northerly portion of the property and walk down to the Charles again via an old dirt road.  Then work your way back via the woods or cut it shorter and exit onto Causeway street and return to the parking area.

hits.name: Monoosnoc Ridge Trail from West St Leominster to Haynes Reservoir
hits.description:
Trail is well marked with blue dots. Varied terrain with lots of ups and downs keeps it interesting. Many sections will be boggy or under water in the spring.

The trail continues for another 5 miles past the reservoir if you would like to extend your hike.

hits.name: Summit Trail to Mount Waddaquaduck Trail
hits.description: This trail makes a steady climb on a moderately used trail with some rocky sections. You will be enclosed by thick forest but the view at the end is well worth the trip.

hits.name: Gummere Woods Loop
hits.description: Nice trail! Lots of options in this area. Sometimes it’s hard to find the trail so you may want to bring the app or downloaded map.

hits.name: Perimeter, Muskrat Pond, Observation, and Hemlock Trail Loop
hits.description:
Caratunk Wildlife Refuge is owned and operated by the Audobon Society of Rhode Island (even though the park is in Massachusetts). Although the property is private, it is open to hikers. Pets must stay at home.

The trails are home to many interpretive signs with info about native bird species.

hits.name: Fort Hill Trail
hits.description: To reach the trailhead, turn onto Fort Hill Road from Route 6. There will be a parking area across from the Captain Penniman house. Pets are not allowed here and it is a great place for birdwatching.

hits.name: Kettlehole and Bay Circuit Mount Misery Loop
Westboro Wildlife Management Area and Chauncy Lake Loop
Franklin Reservoir Loops
hits.description: A great loop around the reservoir that is perfect for kids and dogs!

hits.name: Busby Trail, Spruce Hill Lost Pond and Blackburnian Loop
hits.description: Marked with blue blazes and easy to follow, the Busby Trail takes you through dark spruce plantations, deep hardwood forests, and wildflower fields then past (possibly haunted) cellar holes, to Spruce Hill which has spectacular, almost 360 degree views from its summit. Lost Pond Trail is reportedly hard to follow due to beaver activity. Please use caution if hiking this loop using the Lost Pond Trail. This trail tends to become very wet and muddy during the wet season so wear proper shoes.

hits.name: Great Brook Meadow Pond Loop
hits.description: Easy walking trails through woods and fields mostly around Meadow Pond in Great Brook

hits.name: Burnt Swamp Trail
hits.description:
Please note that this area is surrounded by private property, and the trails are not marked well. Please be respectful and do not enter private lands.

A former dairy farm taken by the town to be used as Conservation Land, Birchwold is nearby the more famous Joe's Rock in Wrentham, MA and is Popular with Birders, walkers, And Eagle Scout Projects.

hits.name: Beech Forest Trail
hits.description:
Dogs are not allowed on designated nature trails at Cape Cod National Seashore at any time, although they are allowed on-leash on the beaches when shorebirds are not nesting as well as not on lifeguard protected beaches during the summertime.

Journey into the heart of a picturesque beech forest, and enjoy great bird watching opportunities, especially in spring and fall. It skirts the shallow Beech Forest Pond. 

Please don't feed the wildlife, including the birds. This can damage the natural balance, and is against the law.

hits.name: Roaring Brook Trail to Deer Hill Falls
Mount Marcy Trail
hits.description:
The Mount Marcy trail provides a short, steep hiking experience with breathtaking views, especially during the fall and spring, when there is less foliage. The south leg of the loop is fairly wide and has many switchbacks and a few steep sections. The easiest hike up Mount Marcy is to take the south leg up and back. The north leg is narrower, has many rocks and roots and more steep sections; nevertheless it is easily do-able if one goes slowly, and then one can return to the parking lot via the south leg. 

The parking lot holds 6-8 cars. In addition to the views and the great short hiking experience, there are three geodetic markers at the summit, and the base of a tower which was used for postal airplane navigation during the 1930's and 40's.

hits.name: Kents Point Trail
Snake Peak Trail
hits.description: This trail is an out-and-back trail. Do not walk on McLean Reservoir Road to make the trail a loop.

hits.name: Lynn Woods Water Tower
hits.description: Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

hits.name: Stony Brook Nature Center & Wildlife Sanctuary
hits.description:
A boardwalk and wooded adventure with plenty of wild flora and fauna. There are admission fees for nonmembers.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of North Street at the east end of the trail. One of them is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is wooden boardwalks (with railings), gravel, or a natural (dirt) surface, and typically at least 3 feet wide.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.35 miles heading clockwise. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a moderately steep section right at the beginning. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. 

All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. According to the sanctuary website, there are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms and the nature center is wheelchair-accessible. 

The Sensory Trail is a rope-guided trail. There are braille and tactile signs along the route and a tactile map available at the nature center. For additional information, visit https://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/stony-brook/about/accessibility

hits.name: Goat Hill Loop
hits.area_name: Blackstone River and Canal State Park

hits.name: Middle Reservoir and South Reservoir via Red Cross Path and Brooks Road
hits.description: Downloading your offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trail is not marked well.

hits.name: Boston Marathon Route
hits.description:
Get familiar with the famous Boston Marathon route! Ride, run, walk or be a spectator at the various mile markers!

Get familiar with the famous Boston Marathon route! Ride, run, walk or be a spectator at the various mile markers!

Why does Urban AdvenTours, a bike touring business have a guide for the Boston Marathon?

Because midnight before the race, all the roads are marked off which makes for one sweet cycling route. You have your choice to either ride under the stars with the midnight riders or cycle with the large group of early-birds before the race. 

What is the Boston Marathon?

An annual marathon that takes place on Patriot's Day. The route starts on the Main street of  Hopkinton, Massachusetts. The track makes its way across various towns and cities, following Route 135, Route 16, and Route 30 (Commonwealth Avenue). Along Comm. Ave the route takes a turn onto Beacon Street and ends on Boylston Street. The finish line is in front of the Boston Public Library of Copley Square in Boston, Massachusetts.

The Boston Marathon is one of the world's best road racing events and also the oldest annual marathon in the world.

This year marks the 115th year of Boston Marathon. More than 26,000 entrants from 90 different countries will be participating, some of which are the fastest distance runners in the world.

hits.name: Dana Commons
hits.description: Walk or bike through history at Dana Commons. Stone walls, cellar holes. No pets please.

hits.name: Winterberry Way, Harrys Way, and Otter Alley Loop
Alewife Linear Park
hits.description:
This paved trail goes from the Alewife T-station in Cambridge to the Sommerville Community Path. It crosses some roads, so take caution in those areas. There are several parks with playgrounds along the route. 

Accessibility: There are designated accessible spaces in the Alewife Station Parking Garage off of Alewife T Station Access Road at the west end of the trail. The trail surface is paved asphalt with a yellow dividing line (cutting the width in half) or brick, and typically at least 8 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

hits.name: Rocky Woods Mega Loop
hits.description: Park on Tower Drive and start at the Tower Trail trailhead on Cedar Hill.  Drop down on the Cedar Hill Trail and bushwack around the Noanet ancient trails (hard to find one of them). Continue to Chickering Lake then Echo Lake to see how the beavers are doing.  Continue on Cheney then over into the Hawthorne and Woodcliff Hills area (older trails).  Return via Wilson Swamp and the Ridge Trail.

hits.name: Ridge Trail and North Loop Trail
High Ledges via Dutch and Mary Barnard to Wolves' Den to Waterthrush Loop
Cape Cod Rail Trail to Brewster
hits.description: Nice landscapes and passing by ponds. Places to stop along the way.

hits.name: Beaver Brook Western Greenway Loop
hits.description: So this is a route through Beaver Brook that includes two sections not noted on all map layers. This includes on unmarked path that parallels a small creek and rides the top of a ridge. Then the trail goes up to the backside of Mackerel Hill, which is the elevation gain you see.

hits.name: New, Holliston, Bypass, Main, Three Sisters and Deer Trail
Mount Norwottuck and Rattlesnake Knob Loop
Strawberry Hill Peak and Powisett Pond Loop
hits.description: Park in Noanet Woodlands parking area off Powisset Street in Dover.  The trailhead and initial trails are in Noanet but then you cross over into the Hale Reservation where the bulk of the hike is located.  Continue up and over Strawberry Hill then down to the beach at Powisset Pond via the Strawberry Hill Trail.  Continue up and around then down to the road which takes you back to the parking area.  Plenty of alternate ways to do this one.

hits.name: Mount Wachusett via Bicentennial, Mountain House, Old Indian,  West Side, Semuhenna, and Pine Hill Trail Loop
hits.description:
This is a great figure eight loop taking visitors over the summit of Mountain Wachusett. 

At the summit, there are signs informing visitors what is visible on the skyline on a clear day. With good visibility, the skyline of Boston is typically visible. 

This is a great place to come to see migratory birds as well.

hits.name: Jacobs Pond to Esker Trail Loop
Mt. Wilcox and Beartown Mountain Trail Loop
hits.description:
From the NE part of the parking lot take the loop trail that connects to the Appalachian Trail.  Take the AT in the N direction (white blazed trail). Continuing on the AT, just before crossing a brook bridge, there will be a small side trail (short walk) that will take you to a beaver pond. After the power line, take the wood road that travels to the west (leaving the AT).  Turn north (right) at the Ski and Bridle Trail (red triangles). 

Upon reaching Mount Wilcox Rd turn left, and walk downhill for 1/2 mi.
Return via the Turkey trail and a CCC wood rd. On the right hand side of the wood rd you can enjoy the Pond. Reach your car via the northern portion of the loop trail.

hits.name: Mount Tom via Metacomet-Monadnock Trail (Short Option)
Tippling Rock via Monson, Nixon, Thirty Rod, and Legion Trails
Habitat Audubon Wildlife Sanctuary Trail
hits.area_name: Habitat Education Center and Wildlife Sanctuary
hits.description:
This is a short walk around the Audubon Wildlife Sanctuary just north of Belmont, MA.  It is a great place for birding. Some parts of the sanctuary are accessible to wheelchairs.

The Habitat Wildlife Sanctuary is all about environmental education with informative signs and a visitor center which often holds art galleries.  There are 2.5 miles of trails within the 90 acre sanctuary for you to explore.  This guide presents one possible loop that will take you past a peaceful urban garden, around a pond and through a meadow into a deciduous and evergreen forest giving you a taste of each environment the area has to offer.  Bring your binnoculars and camera for this beautiful walk.

hits.name: Western Greenway to Hemlock Trail
hits.description: Western and Central Part of Western Greenway.

hits.name: Dry Brook, Lithia Springs, Black Rock, an New England Trail Loop
hits.description:
This hike has great views along the whole trail from the ridgeline looking out at the Holyoke Range and Pioneer Valley. 

There are lots of streams for dogs to play in at the beginning of the hike.

hits.name: D.W. Field Park
hits.description: Parking at the Pond Street gate. Nice loop road and trail option around all four bodies of water: Brockton Reservoir, Waldo Lake, Porter Pond, and 30-Acre Pond.  Started clockwise and continued across South Street to far end of Waldo Pond and the spillway.  Continued back on west side back to the north and the parking area. This is a nice biking option too.

hits.name: Midstate Trail: Route 2 to Mile Hill Road
Mahanna Cobble
hits.description:
Users have reported that the trailhead is a bit hard to find. You pull into the ski area and then the trail sign is at end of the parking lot. 

This is a pleasant hike up to Mahanna Cobble. The first 10 minutes will get your heart rate going, but then it’s steady up the rest of the way to a beautiful view at George’s Bench.

hits.name: Mary V. Flynn, Ice Glen, Laura's Tower Combo
hits.description: Park in the little lot at he end of Park Street, Stockbridge. Start the hike from the bridge across the Housatonic River, then make a 90º turn left. Follow the path by the river (include the little loop at the end) then make your way back to the bridge. At this point, turn left and take the Ice Glen trail (white diamond blazes) as far as it will go (some scrambling required), then double back until you join the Laura's Tower trail to your right (red diamond blazes). Follow this up to the tower (you can climb this for the views), then back to the lot.

hits.name: Copicut Woods
hits.description: A great hike from Yellow Hill Road to the Ed Shed and back.

hits.name: Bay Circuit Trail: Mt. Misery - Walden Pond
Perry's Peak
hits.description: This route passes Richmond Overlook on the way to Perry's Peak.

hits.name: Tekoa Mountain and Westfield Reservoir
hits.description: Tekoa Mountain in Russell, Massachusetts is an invigorating jaunt up steep trails and over crags and boulders to the summit. The southwest and northeast sides of Tekoa Mountain are steep and rugged with frequent cliff faces and rocky overlooks; to the north, the topography gradually flattens out as Tekoa Mountain merges with the upland plateau of Montgomery. The view is well-worth the effort.  Tekoa Mountain is about 1,130 feet at its summit. In comparison, Mount Greylock, the highest point in Massachusetts, is 3,491 feet tall at its summit, in the northwestern town of Adams.  Tekoa Mountain is home to many kinds of wildlife, including deer, bear and coyote. It is also populated by timber rattlers, a fact that is important for visitors to be aware they are here. Tekoa Mountain was named after the biblical fortress and settlement of Tekoa, translated alternately as a place "fastening down" or "a trumpet blast." Trails are not blaze and are considered strenuous and challenging in places.   Once on the ridge the trails flatten out to gradual incline.

hits.name: Manhan Rail Trail: Ferry to Southampton
hits.description:
Some benches and road crossings along the way. This route is a designated National Recreation Trail.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Ferry Street at the northeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with partial edge barriers), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There are painted dividing lines or metal bollards at street crossings along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Bellows Pipe Trail to Ragged Mountain
Midstate Trail through Douglas State Forest
Gooseberry Neck
hits.description:
Drive down the jetty to a sandy parking lot (lots of parking) where there's a beach and fishing. The outer walk around the island is super rocky but manageable. There's also a trail through the brush down the middle of the island. 

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel and sand parking lot off of Gooseberry Island Causeway at the north end of the trail. The trail surface is a natural surface (dirt, rocks, grass, sand). It is typically at least 3 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type.

hits.name: White Oak and Blue Dot Trail Loop
Plymouth Wishbone Walking Trail
hits.description:
Plymouth Wishbone Walking Trail can be difficult at times (especially for new hikers), users report for sturdy hiking boots and the ability to hike at least 7 miles before going onto this trail. 

Remember to bring sunscreen and bug spray.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: North Adams (Eph's Lookout) to Harmon Hill and Bennington
Whitney Spur Bikeway to Wompatuck Bikeway
Wildcat Hill via Red Diamond to Bay Circuit Loop
Mary V. Flynn Trail
hits.description:
A nice pleasant flat short walk along the river.  Completely relaxing and enjoyable.  Good for the whole family.

Accessibility: There is one designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Park Street at the west end of the trail. It does not appear to be van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement (with partial railings) or a natural surface, and typically at least 3 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Southern New England Trunkline Trail From Central St
Atlantic White Cedar Swamp Extended Trail

Bear Mountain via Bear Mountain Road
Quincy Shore
hits.description: Walk the length of Wollaston beach along Quincy Shore Pond. Views of the islands in Boston Harbor and of the Boston Skyline. Parking is also found throughout the route to make this walk shorter.

hits.name: Earl's Trails and Glenna Bell Trail
Goat Peak Loop via T. Bagg Trail to Kay Bee Trail
