hits.name: Upper Charles Rail Trail: Milford to Dopping Brook Wetlands
Goat Peak, Dry Knoll, Mt. Nonotuck Loop
hits.description: Great views - three peaks to enjoy and ruins as well.

hits.name: Gramp's Loop Trail
hits.description: Gentle hills and wide, well marked trail make this an enjoyable walk in the woods. A few well placed benches and great forest views with a section of tall cathedral pines. Easy loop with glimpses of Halfway Pond.

hits.name: RRR Brooks Trail to Shepherd’s Well to Taconic Crest
Amesbury Rail Trail
hits.description:
The Amesbury Riverwalk is currently an out and back walk which passes by the Powow River along the backside of a residential area and through light a manufacturing area. The trail passes under I495 and is commonly used as a bike route but is also a great 2.5 mile trail for walkers right near downtown Amesbury.

The trail features three informational signs about the history of the railway in Amesbury complete with old photographs. Future plans hope to link this to Salisbury and the Newburyport Rail Trail for a continuous through-way between these three towns.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Water Street at the northwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Boston Harborwalk Loop: Pope John Paul II Park
hits.area_name: Pope John Paul II Park Reservation
hits.description:
This paved trail along the Neponset River starts at Pope John Paul II Park and goes north to the boat harbor. 

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Hallet Street at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less), except for steep (8-12%) sections at about uphill/downhill sections at about 0.5 miles uphill, 0.8 miles downhill when going north. Trail goers using wheelchair/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: East Boundary and Stony Brook Path Loop
hits.description:
This paved loop provides access to several unpaved dirt paths within.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the small paved parking lot off of Enneking Parkway at the south end of the trail. However, there are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Turtle Pond Parkway. It has been marked with a waypoint. The trail surface is paved asphalt, and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) sections at about 0.6 miles uphill, 1.0 miles downhill, and 1.7 miles downhill when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. According to the park website, there are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms and accessible fishing areas within the park.

hits.name: Lyman Reserve Trail
hits.description: The Lyman Reserve is a small wooded area on the banks of Red Brook near its outlet to Buttermilk Bay, including a small sandy beach.  It was a 19th century fishing camp so the small network of trails mainly follow the banks of the brook.

hits.name: Wachusett Mountain via North Road and Semuhenna Trails
Bare Hitchcock Loop
hits.description: Sections of the trail closely border private property, including walking down a residential street to complete the loop. Hikers should be respectful while passing through areas close to private residences.

hits.name: Healthy Heart Trail
hits.description:
The Healthy Heart Trail is a very easy, flat hike that can be enjoyed by hikers of any experience level. There are benches along the trail for those that may need breaks and the trail itself is wheelchair accessible. There are views of the Ipswich River; and on a hot day, you can wade into the water. You also have the chance to see the Willowdale Estate via this trail.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved roadside parking lot along Topsfield Road at the northeast end of the trail. However, there are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot marked with a waypoint by the south end of the trail. 

The trail surface is a boardwalk (with edge barriers), sand dust, or a natural surface and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Harris Loop, Nashawahkamuk, Cobble Stone Beach Overlook and Great Sand Bank Overlook
Blue Hills Trail to Elliot tower
Harold B. Clark Town Forest Loop
Round Pond to Island Creek Pond Loop
Independence Greenway Path
hits.description:
This is a very easy trail for hikers of all ages; very little change in elevation throughout. This is also a gorgeous trail to hike if you are here in late September/early October when the oak, birch, and maple trees turn colors. 

There is a small parking lot at the western-most end of the trail (just across Russell Street) and ample parking surrounding the Big Y grocery store (corner of Russell Street and Lowell Street).

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Johnson Street at the southeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, and typically at least 5 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Webb Memorial State Park Loop
Laurel Loop
hits.description:
The Laurel Loop is blue-blazed trail forming a very short (0.75 mile) loop near the Notch Visitor's Center in Amherst.

This is a short and easy trail, suitable for small children. There is steeper uphill climb if you go clockwise, so the easiest is counter-clockwise. This trail partly overlaps with the orange-blazed Robert Frost Trail and white-blazed Metacomet-Monadnock. Be sure to note when the trail turns (marked by a double blue blaze) and do not follow the telephone line.

hits.name: Peninsula, Pipeline, West and East Bog Loop
Appalachian Trail: Beartown to Bald Top
Callahan Park, Henry's Hill, and Welch Reservation Loop
hits.description: A pretty good trail for a long run. There are many intersecting trails, not always well marked, so you need to pay close attention to your route on the app as you go.

hits.name: Bellows Pipe and Thunderbolt Ski Trail Loop
Great Dunes and Truro Beach Loop
Fire Road, Thing One and Thing Two Loop
Appalachian Trail to Old Summit Trail Loop
Batchelder Park Trail Loop
hits.description: This loop starts at the Gardner Lake Beach and travels along the edge of the lake through Bachelder Park. At the crossroads keep left to follow the edge of the lake and turn right up the second main trail called Powow Trail. This is a moderate trail through the woods and can be muddy in the Spring. After a short period of exertion you will reach Batchelder Park with views of the ocean over Seabrook, NH. This is a great place to watch the sunrise! To return to the beach you can take Batchelder Trail which has views over the Amesbury town center through the trees.

hits.name: Wachusett Mountain via Old Indian and Loop Trails
Laurel Lane, Country Road, Charcoal Kiln, and Pitcher Brook Loop
Marsh, Ledge, Witch Hollow and Wildcat Loop
ToT North, North Ridge, Lookout Lane, and Scott Rock Trails Loop
Conant Brook Reservoir
hits.description: Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

hits.name: Skyline Trail, Great Cedar Swamp, and Hawk Hill
Billerica State Forest
hits.description:
easy suburban hike or mountain bike

Nice suburban woods used some by mountain bikers and paint-ballers, but largely forgotten amongst the encroaching development. Three are more beautiful locations to escape to in New England, but this one might be easier to fit into a busy schedule if you live or work in the area.

hits.name: Long Pond, Wellfleet and Newcomb Beach Loop
Pratt's Brook Conservation Area
hits.description: A nice 1.3 mile loop in Acton. A very quiet trail perfect for the family or a hike with the dogs.

hits.name: Boston Harbor Path: Malibu Beach to Pleasure Bay
hits.description:
This fully paved segment of the Boston Harbor Path starts by the McConnell Park and Malibu Beach. It heads north mostly directly along the Harbor, U Mass Boston, the Old Harbor, to Pleasure Bay and Fort Independence. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Denny Street at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings near steep drop-offs), smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. There are painted dividing lines and metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: MA NET: Section 5
hits.description: This portion can be a bit strenuous, but very enjoyable. There are lots of scenic views and a bit of scrambling. This section of the NET preceding Mt. Tom will give you a good workout.

hits.name: J.C. Phillips Nature Preserve Loop
hits.description: There is parking on Cabot Street.

hits.name: High Rock, Wolf Meadow and Tupelo Trail
Saddle Ball Mountain via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
This is a great opportunity to enjoy the Mt Greylock Reservation without actually following the crowds that go around the Greylock summit.  

The trail starts easy, going downhill on easy trails.  Upon reaching the Cheshire Harbor trail, the trail gets a bit rough, and gains some elevation quickly.  To return, you will use a nice portion of the Appalachian Trail.

From Saddle Ball Mountain you can see beautiful views of Mt. Greylock, and just south of the mountaintop you will find another vista spot that will allow you to see upstate New York.

There is plenty of opportunities to enjoy the flora and fauna of Massachusetts.  Almost all of the microclimates are represented.  Plenty of varieties of trees.  And at the end of the hike, on the Jones Nose trail you can enjoy bird watching on a lightly wooded area (mostly a plain with beautiful wildflowers and scattered trees).

hits.name: Harding Beach Point via Monomoy Nature Trail
hits.description: On the mainland (Morris Island Loop area), pets are not permitted from May 1st - September 15th. Pets are permitted, while on a short leash, September 16th - April 30th.

hits.name: Breakneck Ledge and Chestnut Run Loop
Bluff Hill via Billings, Bluff, Bay Circuit Trail
High Ledges via Dutch and Mary Barnard to Waterthrush Loop
Nagog Hill Yellow, Red, and Blue Trail
hits.description: Nagog Hill Conservation Area consists of a 2 mile loop around Nagog Hill and 1 mile loop around Grassy Pond. An easy walk that takes you through meadows, woods and streams.

hits.name: Charge Pond Loop Trail
hits.description: You're hiking on soft sand and dirt most of the time. But make no mistake, this is a wonderful, quiet hike with a lot of beautiful nature.

hits.name: Head of the Meadow Bike Trail
Quansett and Fresh Pond Trails
hits.description: Pretty hazy, couldn't see too far. Lots of frogs littering the path.

hits.name: Gordon College-Culvert Trail
hits.description: An easy trail that is perfect for the whole family! There are many options to take detours and explore the area's network of trails.

hits.name: Kettle Pond Ramble Trail
hits.description: This lovely route follows the road, then woods, then goes by a pond.

hits.name: Friends Trail to Morse Loop to Bay Circuit Trail
Beaver Brook North Reservation Loop
hits.description:
A lot of fun! Tons of trails in the woods. Some overgrown but others maintained. The loop may be very busy in certain spots at certain times.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Trapelo Road at the southwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, packed gravel, or a natural surface, and typically at least 3 feet wide.
 
The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 1.3 miles heading clockwise. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) sections at about 0.7 miles downhill, and 1.4 through 1.7 miles uphill and downhill when going clockwise. 

Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas and steep grades. There are several wheelchair-accessible picnic tables with a firm and stable path and surface, and at least 27 inches of knee clearance.

hits.name: Allandale Woods Trail
hits.description:
This is a fun trail for hikers of all ages! 

Sections of the trail are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating.

hits.name: Kathy's, Algonquin, Bob's, and Old Coach Trails Loop
Bob's Way Loop
hits.description: A fine, and very little-known, set of trails just south of Royal Pond by Route 23. Created in honor of land conservationist Bob Thieriot, the trail system is small, but perfectly formed. It mainly passes through deep woods, and a beaver pond, with a cut-across trail (Cathcart Crossing) to a lookout called Dave's Bench, a lovely little spot where one can rest and picnic.

hits.name: Rabbit Run Rail Bed
Bancroft Castle
hits.description: A short but steep walk up Gibbet Hill to explore the ruins of Bancroft's castle, a expansive westerly view, and Gibbet hill farm. Parking is available at Gibbet Hill Grill during off hours. There is very limited parking off of RT-40 - there is not a trail you can connect to from the restaurant area.

hits.name: Winterberry Way, Taylor Way and Harry's Way Loop
Dana Common and F94 Jet Crash Site
hits.description:
Two historic sites on one out and back hike at the Quabbin Reservoir. The first site is the historic Dana Common, a town that was removed when the Quabbin Reservoir was created. Here the foundations of the old town can be seen as well as site markers at each foundation showing what the building used to look like. The second historic site is the crash site of an F102 military jet. Many pieces of the aircraft remain in the woods to this day and can explored.

Most of this trail is the old road to the town of Dana and is paved but not maintained. Biking is allowed on this portion of the Quabbin. Dogs are not allowed.

hits.name: Pine Hill Loop
hits.description: Park at Farm Pond and proceed southwest down the street to any of the trailheads on your right.  Work your way onto the gas/petro line trail and head north to Farm Road.  Cross Farm Road and continue north looking for a trailhead on your left.  Continue clockwise toward, then around, the Pine Hill ledges and summit.  Drop down to the school then back around to the gas line trail. The Bay Circuit Trail is also an option on the return, look for the trail markers.  A wonderful property, awesome ledges!

hits.name: Metacomet-Monadnock Trail East Through Holyoke
hits.description:
This is Section 8 of the Metacomet-Monadnock Train, from the Notch in Granby to Harris Mountain Road, in the Holyoke Range State park.

This hike includes Mt. Norwottuck and Long Mountain summits, and passes through the Horse Caves and right near Rattlesnake Knob. Unless you are continuing on the M-M trail to Section 9, or also taking a return trip back to the Notch, you must arrange a pickup at the end of this segment of the trail.

hits.name: Lane Conservation Area and Town Forest Loop
hits.description: Access the parking area from the southern side of Holman Street near Northfield Road.

hits.name: Cedar Hill, Wilson Swamp, Cheney Pond and East West Trail
hits.description: This loop follows the edges of the Rocky Woods Reservation, for a total of 6.6 km of wooded hiking. The first portion is moderately steep, up to the top of Cedar Hill, offering limited vistas.  The rest of the walk is through rolling, wooded hillside. It is dog friendly - on leash close to the parking area and off leash otherwise. The trails are well marked, offering a trail map at each major trail intersection. Parking costs $5, unless you are a member of the Trustees of the Reservations.

hits.name: East Street Bogs Loop Trail
Primary Trail around Delaney Pond Loop from Harvard Road
Nanepashemet Road and Reservoir Trail Loop
Goat Peak via Beau Bridge Trail
hits.description: This is a great little loop trail with lots of interesting features.  Part of the trail follows a stream and has a great series of bridges to cross.  From there you climb up hill and eventually get to Goat Peak Tower which offers fabulous views of the valley.  Follow the white trail markers back down the mountain and to the parking area.  Much of the trail is lined in mountain laurel so come in mid June if you want to see it in bloom.

hits.name: Dr. Paul Dudley White Path Short Loop via Charles River Esplanade
Historical Society of Old Yarmouth - Nature Trail
Canalside Rail Trail
hits.description:
About a quarter-mile of the trail around the 2.5-mile mark is along roadways. Wearing a helmet, bright colors, and using lights and flags is always recommended when sharing space with motor vehicles.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of 1st Street at the northeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at the bridge), and typically at least 5 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a moderately steep (5-8%) section at about 3.5 miles when going southbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Rock via Old Pine Nook Road
hits.description: A jeep road, steep at times, that provides fast access to the Pocumtuck Overlook.  Many trails branch off of this road.

hits.name: Roaring Falls
hits.description: This is a brief walk through the woods to a waterfall over huge boulders. During dry periods, the falls are just a trickle and the swimming holes are large puddles. If you like, you can continue hiking up the blue trail and climb Ox Hill, Roaring Mountain, or even Mt Toby from this trailhead. These trails are less commonly used, compared to the Mt Toby trailhead on Reservation Rd.  Park in the lot to the left heading north on 63, before you reach Montague Rd. Leave a $2 donation for those who maintain the parking lot.

hits.name: New Bedford Harborwalk
hits.description:
A nice walk along the shore. There are two parking lots, the directions on here lead you to the boat parking lot (which makes it a longer walk to the lighthouse). There is a lot closer to the lighthouse that you can find easily on Google Maps. Keep an eye out for fiddler crabs!

Users have noted that the Harborwalk path is paved and wheelchair and stroller friendly but these do not go to Palmer Island or the lighthouse and the only way to access those is by climbing over rocks at low tide.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Rodney French Boulevard at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is flat (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Nashua River and Oxbow Trail Loop
Notchview Reservation
hits.description:
Notchview is adjacent to Snowmobile Association of Massachusetts (S.A.M.) Route 91 that links snowmobile trails from CT to VT.  

When to Visit
Year-round, daily, sunrise to sunset. Allow a minimum of 3 hours. Cross-country skiing and snowshoeing available early December to early April, daily, 8AM to 4:30PM.

hits.name: North Skyline, Hallway Path and Accord Path Loop
hits.description: Park in the ski area parking lot then head up the northern-most ski slope. Continue up to the summit of Eliot Hill then work your way around to Wolcott Hill, Hemenway Hill, Hancock Hill, then Houghton Hill before returning via the Accord Path Trail to the base of the ski area.

hits.name: Tyler, Berlin Road Trail, North Gorge and South Overlook Loop
Virginia Woods and Spot Pond Brook Loop
Nelson Memorial Forest Loop via Philips Farm Preserve
Tannery Falls
hits.description: This is a short loop trail up to Tannery Falls and back down. There are several small falls along the brook, but Tannery Falls itself is more impressive at around 70ft.

hits.name: Dudley Porter and Shore Trail Loop
Mount Wachusett via Stage Coach, Harrington/Mid State, Link and Mountain House Trail
Land Mine Challenge
hits.description:
Land Mine Challenge MTB Race Course

This course is mostly entirely on singletrack, you will encounter rocks, roots, berms, pavement (minimal), fast and slow trails. It is a technical course for experienced riders, as you will be riding by, through, or over old bunkers, blasting walls, railway beds, and stone walls.

hits.name: Fernwood Lake (Blue Trail) and Old Salem Trail Loop
Minute Man Park, the Old Bridge, and the Manse
Phelps Trail to the Taconic Crest Trail down the Mills Hollow Trail
Franklin Town Forest Red Loop
hits.description: This loop explores Franklin Town Forest. There are several internal, cut through trails in the middle of the forest. There are also several spur trails.

hits.name: Jericho Town Forest Loop via Concord Road
hits.description:
This trail closes partially periodically for beaver activity.

Well-marked trails with a mix of small and wide paths and some creek crossings.

hits.name: Middle Reservoir Loop via Woodland Road
Middlesex Fells Reservoir and Boojum Rock
Lantern and Corn Cob Loop Trail
Arlington Reservoir Trail
hits.description: Loop around Arlington Reservoir

hits.name: Bird Song, Tall Grass, and Coyote Trail
Paint Mine to Powerline Road, Yellow Trail, and Milk Crate Loop
Robinson State Park Extended Loop
hits.description: Nice trail with great views along Westfield River.  Some elevation change but nothing very difficult.

hits.name: Midstate Trail: Tafts Corner to Browning Pond
Stage Fort Trail
hits.description:
Take the time to explore the rocky coast, soft beach and massive granite rock in this park.

This is the site of the first settlement in Gloucester.  There is a beach, nature trails , ball park, and a massive rock with a plaque on it to check out.  If you time it right you may find yourself in the middle of one of the many festivals the city has here.

hits.name: Central Monoosoc Ridge Trail Loop via MA2
Dinosaur Footprints Trail
hits.description:
DO NOT cross railroad tracks to the river, stay on the designated route.

Imagine small herds of dinosaurs on the shore of a shallow tropical lake as you enjoy a real, up-close look at their fossilized sandstone prints.

hits.name: Poverty Mountain
hits.description: This hike is similar to the nearby Mount Orient, with a similar western view, but without running into other hikers. Most of the trail is wide and well-maintained. The route here follows the Poverty Mountain Trail, then the Poverty Ridge Run, and returns on the Middle Access Road. There is room for about 3 cars at the trailhead on Pratt Corner Road. This is part of the Amherst Watershed, so no vehicles on the trail.

hits.name: MA NET: Section 2
hits.description: Also called the Metacomet-Monadnock Trail, M&M Trail, and M-M Trail

hits.name: Mount Tom and Deadtop via Whiting Reservoir Road
Deer Hill, Rotten Apple, Fuzzy Bunny and Bear Claw Loop
Saugus River Trail to Blue and Yellow Blaze Loop
Wachusett Reservoir and French Hill Loop
hits.description:
Some parts of the trail disappear to overgrowth but if you stick with it you’ll find it and keep moving on.

Early morning hike/walk. Followed all access roads. Great with sneakers that have great tread.

hits.name: Lunden Pond and Temple Brook Loop
Methuen Rail Trail From Hampshire Road
hits.description:
Easy rail trail, perfect spot to get some exercise when most other trails are covered over with snow. Simple 2 miles each way, some nice marshes along the way for birding. Good for bikes, strollers, mobility equipment, etc. 

Accessibility: In the paved parking lot off of Hampshire Road there are designated accessible parking spaces with four striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least five feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle except for a steep uphill 10% section when going south at about 1.2 miles where assistance may be needed especially if using manual equipment.

hits.name: Bay Circuit Trail
hits.description: A nice parking spot at the trailhead; spaces for 5 cars or so. This puts you right on the reservoir. The Bay Circuit Trail runs along the carriage road and there is a more rustic trail option right down on the water. Plenty of birds along the way, woodpeckers, ducks, heron. Pine Hill Rd for the return then a trail to the left which is a rustic carriage trail. Some blowdown but nice, unexpected. This trail gets you to the top of Pine Hill then goes along the Harvard Univ property (they have a campus on the north side of the hill). One option is to stay on the carriage trail which would bring you to the Harvard access road or Parmenter Street.

hits.name: Dry Knoll Trail
hits.description: Clean, well blazed and signed and worn path. Parking on side of road. Trail leads to eyrie house ruins and goats peak.

hits.name: Wapack Trail, Ski Slope, and Mid-State Trail Bypass Loop
hits.description:
From the main Watatic parking lot off 119, follow the Wapack Trail to the summit of Mt. Watatic. 

From the summit, descend down the old ski slope and follow the trail northwest until it meets up with the Mid State Trail again. From here there's the option to also summit Nutting Hill. 

Continue on the Mid State Trail Bypass back to the parking lot.

hits.name: Long Fellow Pond Trail
hits.description: Loop around pretty pond. Extend Trail into Town Forest or connect to Sudbury trail.

hits.name: Swift River Trail and Winsor Dam
Round Mountain Trail
hits.description: Narrow trails, thick understory, some light scrambling.

hits.name: Broad Meadow Sensory Trail
hits.description:
This trail begins at the butterfly garden by the Visitor Center and continues along part of the Holdredge and Frog Pond Trails. It is one of Mass Audubon’s interpretive trails and includes a rope and post guidance system and 14 interpreted stops.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated wheelchair-accessible parking spot with a striped access aisle at the small trailhead lot at the north end. The trail surface is part boardwalk and part packed stone dust. The informational stations along the way are accessible by both print and audio files. The trail width is at least four feet.

The estimated grade is steep (up to 12%) in the first 0.2 miles and then becomes mostly gentle (5% or less) until you return the same way at about 0.8 miles. Some trail goers using mobility equipment may need additional assistance in the steeper sections. Visitors have also reported that there is a stream that does not have a bridge but only rocks to cross over so you may have to run around there. The other trails in the park that are considered wheelchair and stroller friendly are listed on their website here: https://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/broad-meadow-brook/about/trails

hits.name: Rockery Pond and South Esker Loop Trail
Grand Trunk Trail
hits.description:
This is a well-maintained, mostly flat trail. The trail parallels the Mill Brook and Quinebaug East streams.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Sturbridge Road at the northwest end of the trail. It is unclear if they are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is packed gravel or natural surfaces, and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved and uneven surface type. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Collins Pond, Brackett Pond and Delano Pond
Midstate Trail: Whitmanville to Winnekeag Lake
Bridge Creek East Side Ramble Trail
Yellow Trail at Nashoba Brook
hits.description:
This trail has many kiosks and informational signs, both about the flora and fauna in the area, and also about the history of things you can see on the trail.  There are several optional off-shoots (green trails) that you can visit if you want to see even more of these historic sites.

There is a "Trail Through Time" series of signs, that put emphasis on areas that were used both pre-Colonization and after Colonization.

There is substantial parking, both at the north end (off Route 27), and at the south end (off Davis Road).  The north parking area is possibly a bit better, as it contains many signs at the trailhead, including maps and more historical information.

Dogs are allowed, and must controlled either by leash or other effective means.

hits.name: Mount Prospect via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
Mt. Prospect Trail is located within the Mt. Greylock State Reservation and offers two scenic vistas overlooking Williamstown, MA.

From Money Brook Trail:  Beautiful, easy walk along Money Brook approximately 1.9mi then rocky uphill to Mt. Prospect Trail where the terrain becomes rocky, steep and strenuous. Approximately 1mi to first vista and an additional mile to second vista.

From the Appalachian Trail:  Flat then gradual climb approx. 0.5mi to first scenic vista with relatively unobstructed terrain.  Follow the Mt. Prospect Trail approximately 1.0mi to the second vista.

hits.name: Mount Fissell Trail to Alander Mountain Trail
hits.description: If you don't mind part of the hike being on a gravel road, then this can be completed as a loop.  Great views on Alander Mountain, and the trek between Mt. Frissell and Alander Mountain on the South Taconic Trail is very easy and peaceful. A few steep climbs, but the views are worth it.

hits.name: Brewer Brook Dam Trail
hits.description: Brewer Brook Loop section of the Town of Berlin Conservation Land. The trail takes you along the water and through woods with log bridges throughout.

hits.name: Colby Philips Trail via Hanover Greenway
Billy Goat Flow Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Blackstone River and Canal State Park

hits.name: Dartmoor Farm and Slocums River Reserve Loop
Berry Pond via Heart Healthy Trail
Mentzner, Tyler, Sparrow, Howard Ridge, Green Street to Berlin Road Trail
Breakneck Ridge, Puddle and Wolcott Path, and Chestnut Run Loop
Pierre Lallement Bike Path
hits.description:
This guide shows you a quick and safe route via a bike/walking path from the Jamaica Plain Arnold Arboretum/Franklin Park area to downtown Boston.  The trail may not be as spectacular as the Emerald Necklace path but it is very well maintained, paved, and is almost a straight line mostly along T-tracks to downtown.  Use this along with an Emerald Necklace Guide on this site for nice afternoon bike loop.

Accessibility: The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and typically three to six feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle for the most part, with some moderately steep sections up to 8%.

hits.name: Molly Springs Road to Reservoir Trail
Blueberry Hill and Moon Hill Loop
Francis William Bird Park
hits.description: Stroll meandering pathways and cross artisan-built stone bridges at this family-friendly park of open fields, groves of trees, and frog ponds with over 3 miles of trails and paths owned and operated by the Trustees of Reservations!

hits.name: Elm Bank Loop
hits.description: A nice flat loop trail with plenty of parking at the soccer fields parking area.  Route consists of paved road and off-road. Great views along river trail with nice options to explore the interior areas.  This route includes an option out to Dover Road and the bridge over the Charles River (great views).

hits.name: Danvers Swamp Walk
hits.description: Choate Recreational area to the Rail-trail with swamp-walk & little bit of forest mixed in...

hits.name: Tri-Town, Harrys Way and Hill Trail Loop
Chicopee Paved Trail
hits.description:
Nice walk around the lake, and Westover airport. Many different options within the park, this trail is fully paved.

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Park Entrance Road at the east end of the trail. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and typically at least 5 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.45 miles heading westbound.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.5 through 0.7, 0.9 through 1.0, and 1.8 through 2.0 when going counterclockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Hathaway’s Pond Loop
hits.description: Short, easy, and pretty with a pond. Some areas are rough because they have roots or rocks in the path.

hits.name: Norton's Tree Farm Loop via Squam, Dennison, and Luce Trails
hits.description: Please respect neighbors and do not traverse private property without permission. This trail starts on Squam Road, then follows Squam Path northwest to the Norton Tree Farm. It eventually circles around, joining the Dennison Trail then the Luce Trail for a bit. The trail then reaches Whale's Jaw and then returns to the parking area.

hits.name: J. Harry Rich and Oxbow Loop Trail
hits.description:
The J. Harry Rich Trail is a wide, flat, maintained path. The Oxbox Trail is a secondary trail in the state forest that is more narrow. This section of the loop travels along the banks of the Nashua River looking out at some islands.

Hunting is permitted, so remember to wear blaze orange during hunting season.

hits.name: Shawsheen River and Vale Reservation Loop
Knuckup Hill (Sweatt Hill) and Trout Pond
Upper Highland Lake Trail
hits.area_name: Daughter of the American Revolution (D.A.R.) State Forest

hits.name: Snake Hill via Red Trail and White Trail Loop
Briar Swamp Loop via Luce Trail
Nobscot Lookout Tower via Monson, Pierce, Tower, Jethro Loop
Stow Town Forest Blue, Yellow and White Loop
Midstate Trail Waterfall Loop
hits.description:
This is one of the most scenic walks in Douglas State Forest with constant views of the water at the beginning. 

The trail has a lot of rolling elevation change. It is a great place to go for a jog or a walk!

hits.name: High Ledges Outer Loop and Shelburne Fire Tower
Paul Revere Ride to Freedom Bike Tour
hits.description: This guide takes you from the Old North Church in Boston's North End and follows Revere's ride on April 18, 1775. The Paul Revere Ride to Freedom takes you from the Old North Church in Boston's North End and follows Revere's ride on April 18, 1775 through Charlestown, Lexington and Concord. Recount the events leading up to the Revolutionary War and the great history of Massachusetts in the War for Independence.

hits.name: Emerald Necklace, Olmsted Park, and Arnold Arboretum
hits.description:
This loop of the Emerald Necklace has beautiful greenery, ponds, and nicely paved pathways.  Great for running, biking, and walking.  Continue North of Olmstead Park and you can take the path all the way to the Boston Common. This trail is accessible by the green line (Riverway stop).

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Pond Avenue at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete (with partial railings). It is typically 4 to 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest sections are at about 0.7 and 4.7 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the south end of the trail.

hits.name: Ellis Land, Tower and Bay Circuit Trail
Simon Willard Woods to Egg Rock Loop
Dudley Porter and Castle Trail Loop
Barre Falls Dam Trail
hits.description:
There is something to do all year long! Enjoy the season! 
Take a stroll along the Ware River and marvel at the sites you see.




Barre Falls Dam is located within the towns of Hubbardston, Barre, Oakham, and Rutland, Massachusetts. Nestled within the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation (MDCR) 22,000 acre Ware River Watershed, the area offers many recreational opportunities. Recreational activities at Barre Falls Dam include canoeing, bike riding, picnicking, hunting, fishing, hiking, sightseeing, horseback riding, cross-country skiing, horseshoes, volleyball, and wildlife observation. There is something for all visitors to enjoy. The recreational benefits offered at Barre Falls Dam are an "extra dividend" to the main purpose of this flood damage reduction project.

hits.name: Twin Pond via Taconic Crest Trail to Taconic Skyline Trail
D. Isabel Smith Monomoy River Conservation Lands Trail
hits.area_name: D. Isabel Smith Monomoy River Conservation Lands

hits.name: Pitcher Brook to Laurel Lane Circuit
hits.description: This is a well-marked, well maintained set of trails. It is also very beautiful, even compared to the other beautiful trails in Western Massachusetts. Give yourself ample time to enjoy the brooks and waterfalls, because there are many lovely spots, each one more enticing than the last.

hits.name: Cowassock Woods Yellow, Blue, Red Loop
hits.description: Nice 500+ acre forest just south of the Framingham line and behind the Framingham Golf Course. The power line runs through the property and there is a huge water tank in the southeast corner with very nice graffiti. Interesting history too, during colonial times witches from Salem would take shelter here in the caves.

hits.name: Herb Hadfield Red, Blue, Yellow, and Green Loop
hits.description: This trail is managed by the Westport Land Conservation Trust- https://westportlandtrust.org
